revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2013}}
The '''Hunchun incident''' (October 2, 1920) was a reported raid on a [[Japan]]ese consulate in Manchuria resulting in the death of thirteen Japanese.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} The Japanese government used this incident to justify sending thousands of Imperial Japanese troops into [[Manchuria]] on October 5, 1920. These escalations culminated with the [[Battle of Qingshanli]] (October 21–26, 1920) between [[Japan]] and the Korean Independence Army,{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} where [[Koreans|Korean]] rebels fought Japanese soldiers.
==Background==
For more than a decade prior to Korea’s [[March 1st Movement]] (1919) nationalist groups of Korean rebels, many of whom were former soldiers in the Korean army, organized into various pro-independence factions in Manchuria.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Due to its strategic location across the Korean border, guerilla fighters could effectively launch raids on Japanese consular police stations, and then retreat back to the Chinese side of the boundary.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 44.</ref> For example, Hong Pomdo (a previous [[Righteous Army]] leader) created the Korean Independence Army and trained so-called independence fighters in [[Yanji]]. Additionally, the Northern Route Military Headquarters was established under the leadership of So Il, with Kim Chwajin commanding more than four hundred independence fighters at its officer training school. Separately, Yi Tonghwi also trained over 3,000 independence fighters in Hunchun and armed them with weapons provided by the Red [[Bolshevik]] army.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 35.</ref>
Responding to the March 1st Movement’s failure to secure independence and arouse international sentiments toward the Koreans’ plight under Japanese colonial rule, disaffected Koreans came together on April 13, 1919 in Shanghai to form a republican Korean provisional government with the hope of working together with the independence factions in Manchuria to eventually obtain freedom from Japan.<ref>Michael E. Robinson, 2007, Korea’s Twentieth-Century Odyssey: A Short History (Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press).</ref>
As the momentum behind Korean independence movements in Manchuria increased, Japanese consular police chief Suematsu Kichiji became increasingly concerned about increasing radical Bolshevism among Koreans. To try and suppress these movements, he ordered numerous illegal police raids on suspected radical Jiandao base camps, which were protested by local Chinese leaders.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 45.</ref> While it is clear that some of the Korean guerrilla fighters in Manchuria were influenced by leftist ideologies, the major factions primarily supported the [[Shanghai Provisional Government]] and were focused primarily on Korean independence and self-determination.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 35.</ref>
Angered by the Japanese suppression of the March 1st Movement, Korean independence fighters in Manchuria began increasing their raids against Japanese border posts, killing numerous Japanese guards, with the eventual goal of advancing into Korea to remove the Japanese.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 36.</ref> During the early summer months of 1920, Korean rebels fought with Japanese troops in thirty-two battles along the border. After one particular Japanese counterattack, Hong Pomdo’s forces surrounded and killed 120 Japanese soldiers and wounded more than 200.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 36.</ref>
==Attack and Controversy==
In effort to contain the Korean rebels, Japan petitioned both [[Tokyo]] and the Chinese government to help, but received little assistance.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 45.</ref> Subsequently, on October 2, 1920, a Japanese consulate in the Chinese city of [[Hunchun]] in [[Jilin]] Province was attacked and burned to the ground purportedly (according to Japanese sources) by the Korean Independence Army, killing thirteen Japanese people.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |title=Text of Bryce EUlogies and Statement on Siberia |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/01/24/98975084.pdf |accessdate=June 13, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=January 24, 1922}}</ref> It was further reported that the “bandits” carrying out this attack “committed indiscriminate acts of murder and pillage” and “looted local shops.”<ref name="NYT"/><ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 46.</ref>
Many South Korean historians maintain, however, that the attack on Hunchun was not carried out by the Korean rebels, but rather was staged by the Japanese to justify incursion into Manchuria.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 47.</ref> Some South Korean sources further believe that the attack was coordinated with Chinese bandit leader Ch'ang-chiang-hao who had been bribed by the Japanese to carry out the attack with several bandits in order to incriminate the Koreans. These sources maintain that Chang went further than the Japanese had requested him to in the scale of his attack.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Other South Korean scholars even maintain that the entire incident was a complete Japanese fabrication.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 37.</ref>
[[North Korea]] is likewise skeptical about the Japanese narrative of the incident, with official sources recently asserting that “the Japanese imperialists cooked up the ‘Hunchun incident’ in which they hurled mounted bandits into attacking their consulate and kicked up a wholesale whirlwind of suppression against Koreans in Northeast China under that pretext.”<ref>"North Korea Criticizes Japan's ‘Punitive Operations’ in 1920." BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific, Oct 02, 2009, http://search.proquest.com/docview/460755521</ref>
Though it is difficult for historians to determine who was behind the attack, or whether the incident actually took place, this controversial event is historically significant because Japan used it to justify its escalated military intervention in Manchuria.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 47.</ref> Japan petitioned and received permission from China to send 15,000 troops from the 19th Division of the [[Chosen Army]] of Japan to contain the Korean rebel armies in Jilin province.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
==Aftermath==
In reaction to the Hunchun incident, a Japanese punitive “Jiandao Expedition” was accordingly sent to Manchuria, and used “search and destroy” patrols to suppress the guerrilla fighters by carrying out numerous arrests and executions.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 47.</ref> By December 1920, a Korean Commission report described that Japanese soldiers had burned down thirty-two villages and killed “all the male inhabitants of the [Hunchun] district, and massacred 145 peaceful inhabitants.” One house was reportedly burned down with “women and children inside.”<ref>“Koreans Charge Cruelty,” New York Times, December 24, 1920, https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/12/24/103519339.pdf</ref>
Though Korean independence forces in Manchuria were never effectively organized under the leadership of the Shanghai Provisional Government, they did achieve notable military victories against the Japanese brigades.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) pp. 33-34.</ref> The most significant of these was the [[Battle of Qingshanli]], where about 400 Korean rebels were able to defeat the better-trained Japanese after four days of intense combat.<ref>http://www.asianinfo.org/asianinfo/korea/history/independence_army.htm</ref> In this battle the Koreans killed about 1,200 Japanese soldiers while losing only 60 of their own.<ref>Kang Man-gil, 1994, A History of Contemporary Korea (United Kingdom: Global Oriental) p. 37.</ref> However, according to Japanese records, 11 soldiers were [[killed in action]], 24 wounded.<ref>陸軍第十九師團司令部 「間島事件鮮支人死傷者調」 大正十年二月二十五日</ref>
In early 1921, after a series of skirmishes and retreats on both sides, as well as criticism from local Chinese authorities and the international community, most members of the 19th Division withdrew from eastern Manchuria.<ref>Erik W. Esselstrom, 2005, Rethinking the Colonial Conquest of Manchuria: The Japanese Consular Police in Jiandao, Modern Asian Studies 39, (February) vol. 1: 48.</ref> Some of the socialist-leaning Korean rebels were then recruited by the Red Bolshevik army to assist in its civil war prior to the formation of the [[Soviet Union]].{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:1920 in China]] [[Category:Military raids]] [[Category:International incidents]] [[Category:October 1920 events]]

<!-- notability|Biographies|date=August 2014 --> {{Infobox person |name = Jennifer Gilbert |image = File:Jennifer Gilbert.jpg |birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1968|12|24}} |birth_place = |death_place = |occupation = Entrepreneur, TV personality |alma_mater = [[University of Vermont]] |known_for = Founder of ''Save the Date'' |citizenship = United States |networth = |residence = [[New York City|Greater New York City]] |salary = |spouse = |children = }}
'''Jennifer Gilbert''' (born December 24, 1968) is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[TV personality]]. She is the founder and chief visionary officer of ''Save the Date'', a [[New York City|New York]]–based special events company. She was named one of the ''entrepreneurs of the year'' by [[Ernst & Young]] for her event planning company, ''Save the Date'' in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enchanted Evenings: New York's Top Event Planners|author=Polster, Allison|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/new-yorks-top-event-planners|website=[[Gotham (magazine)|gotham-magazine.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also appeared on the TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernst, Amanda|title=Jennifer Gilbert Reacts To Her Hilarious ‘Real Housewives’ Debut|url=http://www.crushable.com/2010/05/07/entertainment/exclusive-jennifer-gilbert-reacts-to-her-hilarious-real-housewives-debut/|date=May 7, 2010|website=crushable.com|publisher=[[Defy Media]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ref1">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Amy|title=When a 20-Year-Old Secret is Revealed: 'I Refuse to Be A Victim'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amy-palmer/jennifer-gilbert_b_1519270.html|date=May 7, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Cruz, Clarissa|author2=Bailly, Jenny|url=http://www.oprah.com/style/female-authors-model-summer-fashion-under-100|title=7 Authors Model Summer's Most Sizzling (Under-$100!) Outfits|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Gilbert graduated from the [[University of Vermont]] in 1990 and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Consumer market|Consumer Marketing]] with a minor in Business. After graduation Gilbert moved to [[New York City]]. In 1991, at the age of 22, a stranger attacked her, stabbing her 37 times with a screwdriver before leaving her for dead.<ref name="ref1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Scars You Don't See|url=http://www.marieclaire.com/world-reports/jennifer-gilbert-attack|website=[[Marie Claire|marieclaire.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/finally-an-anniversary-to_b_10228850.html|title=Finally, an Anniversary to Celebrate|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Abbasi, Jennifer|url=https://www.success.com/article/jennifer-gilbert-woman-warrior|title=Jennifer Gilbert: Woman Warrior|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
After recovering, she decided to become an [[Event planning|event planner]] and started ''Save the Date'', a New York based [[event planning]] company, in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/201207/burt-helm/jennifer-gilbert-save-the-date-how-i-did-it.html|title='Why I Will Never Be a Victim'|date=June 28, 2012|magazine=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How I Rebuilt My Life After Being Attacked|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/how-i-rebuilt-my-life-after-attack_b_1581340.html|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=August 6, 2012|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> In 2010 she sued a dating company with similar name called Save the Dating, the company went off business after lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cowles, Charlotte|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2010/04/new_housewife_jennifer_gilbert.html|title=New Housewife Jennifer Gilbert Sues New York Matchmaking Business; Gerunds Involved|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 9, 2010|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> The company has rendered services to many notable companies including several in [[Fortune 500]] companies and has been retained by clients such as [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and singer [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert - Who is She|url=http://www.ladieswholaunch.com/magazine/jennifer-gilbert/1094|publisher=ladieswholaunch.com|date=May 11, 2004|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/video/277455|title=Jennifer Gilbert Bounced Back From a Near-Fatal Attack to Find Massive Business Success|author=Schultz, Erin|website=Entrepreneur|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
She is also the co-owner of Portamee, a [[baby carrier]] company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portamee - who are WEe|url=http://www.portamee.com/who.html|publisher=portamee.com|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also authored a book, ''I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag'', in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Never Promised You a Goodie Bag: A Memoir of a Life Through Events--the Ones You Plan and the Ones You Don't|url=https://www.amazon.com/Never-Promised-You-Goodie-Events/dp/B00B558OSO|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jennifer Gilbert, Author Of Memoir 'I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag,' Talks Success After Violence|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/14/jennifer-gilbert-i-never-promised-you-a-goodie-bag_n_1516243.html|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018|date=May 14, 2012}}</ref> In her book, she discussed about how her life changed after being attacked at a young age and then how she got control on her life and started a successful company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert|date=May 17, 2012|publisher=myfoxny.com|accessdate=May 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819012819/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert |archivedate=August 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She spoke at [[TEDx]] [[Barnard College|Barnard College Women]] sharing her entrepreneurial spirit and philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurial Spirit: Jennifer Gilbert at TEDxBarnardCollegeWomen|url=http://socksonanoctopus.com/ted-talks-entrepreneurial-spirit-jennifer-gilbert/|publisher=Soccks on an Octopus|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==TV appearances== She appeared as herself in the [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo's]] hit TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=New 'Housewife' Jennifer Gilbert Loses Airtime, Cut From Reunion Special|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|author=Rancilio, Alicia|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|date=February 6, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=May 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129085209/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|archivedate=November 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She was the party planner for [[Jill Zarin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet NYC’s new ‘Real Housewives’ set to shake up the show|url=https://nypost.com/2010/04/01/meet-nycs-new-real-housewives-set-to-shake-up-the-show/|date=April 1, 2010|publisher=[[nypost.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Eber, Hailey}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1994, Gilbert met her husband, a [[Wall Street]] Executive, Bennett Egeth and the two were married in [[New York City]] 7 years later.
Gilbert lives in [[New York City]] with her husband, their daughter and twin boys.<ref>{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Jennifer Gilbert and Bennett Egeth|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/01/style/weddings-celebrations-vows-jennifer-gilbert-and-bennett-egeth.html|date=December 1, 2002|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Louie, Elaine}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gilbert, Jennifer}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Event planners]]

revision.comment: date format consistency
revision.text:
{{news release|1=article|date=August 2016}} {{sources|date=April 2015}} '''Let's do it 2008''' ({{lang-et|Teeme ära 2008}}) is the largest campaign to activate civic society in [[Estonia]] since the [[Singing Revolution]] in 1988.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} '''[[Let's Do It! World]]''' is a global campaign for cleaning all countries that grew out of Let's do it 2008.
Over 50,000 people, or approximately 4% of the population of 1.3 million, participated in the cleanup of the forests and countryside, which would be proportionally equal to 15.3 million people in the United States, or 57 million people in India. Momentum for the event was built up with a media campaign from October 2007 to April 2008. The action was carried out during one day on 3 May 2008. More than 10,000 tons of garbage were removed from the country's forest in about 5 hours for less than 500,000 euros. Under normal circumstances it would have taken the government 3 years and 22.5 million euros to accomplish a similar feat. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Teeme ara mobile.jpg|thumb|300px|Let's do it map on mobile phone]] -->
==Organizers== The initial team was: * [[Rainer Nõlvak]] * [[Toomas Trapido]] * [[Kadri Allikmäe]] * [[Henri Laupmaa]]
The group met at 29 August 2007 as recorded in the first protocol.
Other people of the main team: * [[Ahti Heinla]] * [[Eva Truuverk]] * [[Tiina Urm]] * [[Anneli Ohvril]] * [[Jüri-Ott Salm]]
==Spreading the model== * Since then Latvia has copied the event in September 2008 with 40,000 volunteers. Lithuania and Latvia did larger scale actions in April 2009 with 150,000 volunteers. * The international cleanup action was announced in March 2009 and the city of Bengaluru (Bangalore) in India did similar action on 16 August 2009. * On 17 April 2010 a similar event was organized in Slovenia - ''[[Let's Clean Slovenia in One Day!]]'' (''Očistimo slovenijo v enem dnevu'') with 12% of population participating (250.000 volunteers). * In 2010 it is planned by Portugal (20 March), Romania (September), Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Moldova, Italy, France, Indian city of Delhi, capital of Ukraine Kyiv and some other Ukrainian towns.
This has led to the international action "[[Let's Do It! World]]" and the creation of [[World Cleanup Day]].
==External links== * [http://www.letsdoitworld.org Let's Do It World site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722000250/http://www.teeme.info/ Let's do it spinoff projects]
== Country teams == * [http://www.limparportugal.org/ Portugal] * [http://www.mesdarom.lt/ Lithuania] * [http://www.talkas.lv/ Latvia] * [http://www.teeme2008.ee/?setlang=eng Estonia] * [http://www.letsdoitromania.ro Romania] * [http://hai.md/ Moldova] * [http://letsdoititaly.org/ Italy] * [http://www.ocistimo.si Slovenia] * [http://www.letsdoitdelhi.org Delhi] * [http://www.cbengaluru.com/ Bangalore] * [http://letsdoit.org.ua/ Ukraine] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120502110054/http://www.letsdoitlebanon.org/ Lebanon] * [http://www.keepitcleanday.nl/ Netherlands] * [http://sdelaem.info/ Russia]
== News and videos == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A5GryIDl0qY Youtube video: Country clean-up project "Lets Do It 2008" / Teeme Ära 2008] * [http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1813749/campaigners_organize_mass_cleanup_via_internet/ Campaigners organize mass cleanup via internet] * [https://archive.is/20090519222958/http://www.tigerprises.com/tag/cleanup/ Tigerprises: Innovation award goes to Let's do it] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509032753/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iXHC_GRa3lblAUSZfJts6peFNm3Q AFP: Software gurus launch cleanup of Estonia] * [http://www.vimeo.com/tag:teeme Video about the action in Vimeo done by team members]
[[Category:Organized events]] [[Category:2008 in Estonia]] [[Category:Events in Estonia]]

page.title: List of Cuba–United States aircraft hijackings

revision.comment: added [[Category:United States crime-related lists]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Cuba-Florida map.jpg|250px|right|thumb|[[Cuba]] is 90 miles (145 kilometres) south of Florida in the United States]] [[Aircraft hijacking]] incidents between the United States and [[Cuba]] were at their height between 1968 and 1972. These incidents have variously been attributed to [[terrorism]], extortion, flight for political asylum, mental illness, and transportation between the two countries as a result of the ongoing antagonistic [[Cuba-United States relations]] and the Communist government restrictions against Cubans attempting to leave Cuba.<ref name="test">[http://www.start.umd.edu/publications/lafree_dugan_aerial_hijackings.pdf Testing a rational choice model of airline hijackings] Study of data {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822080601/http://www.start.umd.edu/publications/lafree_dugan_aerial_hijackings.pdf |date=August 22, 2006 }}</ref> Subsequent measures by both governments contributed to a gradual reduction of reported incidents towards the mid-1970s. Governmental measures included an amendment to [[Cuban law]] which made hijacking a crime in 1970, the introduction of metal detectors in U.S. airports in 1973, and a joint agreement between the U.S. and Cuba signed in Sweden to return or prosecute hijackers.<ref name="test" />
Below is a non-comprehensive list of hijacking incidents of aircraft between Cuba and the United States. {{TOC right}}
== 1950s == Before the Cuban Revolution: * '''April 9, 1958''' A Douglas DC-3, ( CU-T266) piloted by Capt. Armando Piedra, Co-piloted by Ramon J. Vazquez (el Niño). [[Cubana de Aviación]] is hijacked en route from [[José Martí International Airport]], [[Havana]] to [[Abel Santa Maria Airport|Santa Clara Airport]]. The aircraft landed at [[Manuel Crescencio Rejón International Airport|Mérida-Rejón Airport]], [[Mexico]] where the hijack ended. This is considered first hijacking to take place in the Western Hemisphere and likely orchestrated by Fidel Castro.<ref name=ASN090458>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19580409-0 |title=Hijacking description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> * '''April 12, 1958''' The crew of a [[Cuban Airlines]] [[DC-3]] with 12 passengers on board, diverted their flight from [[Havana]] to [[Santa Clara, Cuba|Santa Clara]] in Central Cuba, and flew, instead, to [[Miami, Florida]]. One of the passengers, [[United Press]] reporter Harold Lidin, said that the decision to defect was apparently made after take off.<ref>United Press, "Plane Commandeered, Flown Out of Cuba", ''The Washington Post and Times Herald'', Washington, D.C., Monday April 14, 1958, Volume 81, Number 130, page A5</ref> * '''April 13, 1958''' A [[Cuban Airlines]] DC-3 is hijacked by three crew members, forcing it to fly to Miami.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19580413-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 22, 1958''' [[Cuban Airlines]] Flight 266 is hijacked by 3 rebels who diverted the plane to a rebel airfield in the [[Sierra Maestra]] mountains.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19581022-2|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''November 1, 1958''' A [[Cubana de Aviación]] Flight 495, a [[Vickers Viscount]], en route from Miami to [[Varadero]] to [[Havana]] is hijacked by Cuban militants. The hijackers were trying to land at Sierra Cristal in Eastern Cuba to deliver weapons to [[Fidel Castro]]'s rebels. As night approached, the plane ran out of fuel and tried an emergency landing at the Preston sugar mill. It did not make it and instead landed in the ocean and broke apart, killing most passengers and crew. There were six survivors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/19/usa-cuba|title=Relatives claim passenger in 1958 plane crash off Cuba was a hijacker|first=McClatchy|last=newspapers|date=November 19, 2008|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> * '''November 6, 1958''' Cubana de Aviación Flight 482, a DC-3, is hijacked by rebels and flown to a rebel airfield.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19581106-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref>
After the Cuban Revolution: * '''April 10, 1959''' A COHATA DC-3 is hijacked by six rebels. They fatally shot the pilot and forced the co-pilot to fly to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19590410-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''April 15, 1959''' A plane is hijacked from Cuba to Miami. The hijackers were four members of Batista's Army (three were from the SIM—the Military Intelligence—and one was an aviation mechanic). The airplane is returned by the U.S.<ref name="hijacked">{{cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/urrib2000/Civ8-e.html |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |date=October 27, 2009 |work=archive.org |deadurl=yes |df=mdy |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5knswLjCG?url=http://www.geocities.com/urrib2000/Civ8-e.html |archivedate=October 26, 2009 }}</ref> * '''April 16, 1959''' An Aerovías Cubanas Internacionales [[C-46]] is forced to land in the United States by four men with guns.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19590416-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''April 25, 1959''' A Cubana de Aviación Vickers Viscount is taken by four hijackers and diverted to [[Key West]], Florida.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19590425-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 2, 1959''' a Viscount of Cubana de Aviación is hijacked on a flight from Havana to [[Antonio Maceo Airport]], [[Santiago de Cuba|Santiago]]. The aircraft landed at [[Miami International Airport]].<ref name=ASN021059>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19591002-0 |title=Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref>
== 1960s == * '''April 12, 1960''' A Cubana Vickers Viscount is hijacked by three crew members and a passenger and diverted to Miami. After landing, the hijackers demanded political asylum in the United States.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19600412-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''July 5, 1960''' A Cubana [[Bristol Britannia]] 138 is seized by two co-pilots and diverted to Miami.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19600705-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> *'''July 17, 1960''' A Cubana Vickers Viscount is hijacked by the pilot at gunpoint and diverted to Kingston, Jamaica where the pilot claimed political asylum.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19600717-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''July 28, 1960''' The captain of a Cubana DC-3 and two passengers forced the copilot out of the cockpit. The captain diverted the plane to Miami and requested political asylum.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19600728-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 29, 1960''' Cubana Flight 905, a DC-3, is hijacked by the co-pilot who took an air marshal hostage and forced the plane to fly to Key West. A shooting killed the marshal. The co-pilot and eight passengers involved in the hijack request asylum in the United States; two other passengers also request asylum.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19601029-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''December 8, 1960''' A Cubana aircraft crashed near Cienfuegos after five Cubans attempted to hijack the plane to the United States. A gun battle killed one person before the flight crashed.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19601208-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''January 1, 1961''' A Cubana Bristol Britannia 318 is hijacked by two people and diverted to New York City.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610101-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''May 1, 1961''' Antulio Ramirez Ortiz hijacks [[National Airlines (1934-1980)|National Airlines]] Flight 337, a Convair 440, from [[Miami International Airport]] to Cuba.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/hijackers/suspected-spying.htm|title= Hijacker: Cuba Suspected Spying|last1=Perez|first1=Miguel|work=The Miami Herald|pp=1B, 2B|date=November 7, 1975}}</ref> * '''July 3, 1961''' A Cubana DC-3 is hijacked by 14 people and diverted to Miami.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610703-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''July 24, 1961''' [[Eastern Air Lines]] Flight 202, a [[Lockheed L-188 Electra]], is hijacked to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610724-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''July 31, 1961''' [[Pacific Air Lines#Hijacking attempt|Pacific Air Lines Flight 327]], a DC-3, is hijacked by Bruce Britt Sr., demanding to be taken to Cuba. The pilot and a ticket agent were both shot by the hijacker, who was overpowered by the copilot and three passengers while the plane was on the ground.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610731-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''August 3, 1961''' [[Continental Air Lines]] Flight 54, a Boeing 707, is hijacked to Cuba. The plane is later [[Continental Airlines Flight 11|destroyed]] in a suicide bombing the next year.<ref>{{ASN accident|title=N70775|id=19610803-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''August 9, 1961''' [[Pan Am]] Flight 501, a DC-8, is hijacked to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610809-2|type=Hijacking}}</ref> On the same day, a Cubana C-46 experienced an attempted hijacking by 5 Cubans. Two guards on the plane tried to stop him. A gun battle killed the captain, a hijacker and one guard. The plane made an emergency landing in a sugar cane field. The remaining four hijackers fled the scene.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19610809-3|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 26, 1965''' [[National Airlines (1934-1980)|National Airlines]] Flight 209, a Lockheed L-188 Electra, is hijacked by a Cuban with a pellet gun. Wanting to rescue his family in Havana, he is taken down by the crew with a fire axe.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19651026-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''November 17, 1965''' [[National Airlines (1934-1980|National Airlines]] Flight 30, a DC-8, experiences an attempted hijack by a 16-year-old boy armed with a gun demanding to be taken to Cuba. He fired six shots through the floor before being overpowered by a passenger.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19651117-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''March 27, 1966''' Angel María Betancourt Cueto, armed with a pistol, tries to hijack a Cubana Ilyushin Il-18 (CU-T831) from [[Santiago de Cuba]] to Havana, with 97 persons, in an attempt to reach the U.S. The pilot, Fernando Álvarez Pérez, opposed the hijacking and landed in Havana. The hijacker then killed Álvarez and armed guard Edor Reyes, seriously wounding the copilot Evans Rosales. The event had a large effect on Cubans. The hijacker later was caught and executed.<ref name="hijacked" /> * '''August 6, 1967''' A [[Aerocondor]] [[C-54]] (HK-757) is hijacked to Cuba by five Colombians.<ref>{{ASN accident|title=HK-757|id=19670806-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''September 9, 1967''' An [[Avianca]] C-47 (HK-101) was hijacked by three passengers shortly after takeoff and diverted to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|title=HK-101|id=19670909-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''November 20, 1967''' Louis Gabor Babler, born in Hungary, successfully hijacks a Crescent Airline [[Piper Aztec|Piper Apache]] from [[Hollywood, Florida]] to Cuba; the plane was scheduled to go to the [[Bahamas]].<ref name="Chronology">{{cite web|url=http://cuban-exile.com/doc_176-200/doc0180.html|title= Chronology of Incidents of Cuban Political Violence in the United States from Jan 1965 to Mar 1976}}</ref>
=== 1968 === * '''February 17''' Thomas J. Boynton hijacks a private charter Piper Apache from [[Marathon, Florida]] to Cuba. He returned to the United States via Canada on November 1, 1969 and was sentenced to 20 years for kidnapping.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''February 21''' Lawrence Rhodes hijacked [[Delta Air Lines]] Flight 843, a [[Douglas DC-8|DC-8]], from [[Tampa]], Florida to Cuba with 108 other crew and passengers aboard, including golfer [[Barbara Romack]]. Cuban authorities provided the passengers with lemonade, coffee, cigarettes, and pictures of [[Che Guevara]] and the plane was released after three hours. Rhodes surrendered in Spain on February 10, 1970. A January 4, 1971 hijacking charge against him is dismissed; he was committed to a mental institution; on July 8, 1971 he returns to prison; he is sentenced to 25 years for robbery on July 17, 1972.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 5''' Three people hijacked a [[Avianca]] C-54 (HK-136) and diverted to Santiago, Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|title=HK-136|id=19680305-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''March 12''' Three Cubans hijack [[National Airlines Flight 28]], a DC-8 from Tampa, Florida to Cuba; all are fugitives.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 21''' An [[AVENSA]] [[Convair 440]] is hijacked to Cuba by three passengers.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19680321-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''June 19''' A [[Viasa|VIASA]] DC-9 from Miami is hijacked 15 minutes after takeoff from Santo Domingo and diverted to Santiago, Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19680619-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''June 29''' [[Southeast Airlines]] Flight 101 is hijacked by one person and diverted to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19680629-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''July 1''' Velasquez Fonseca, born in Cuba, hijacks [[Northwest Orient Airlines]] Flight 714, a [[Boeing 727]], from Chicago to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''July 12''' Leonard Bendicks hijacks a [[Cessna 210]] from [[Key West]], Florida, to Cuba. He is deported to the U.S. in September 1968. On March 4, 1971, he is sentenced to 10 years for kidnapping.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''July 17''' Hernandez Leyva, a Cuban, hijacks [[National Airlines (1934–1980)|National Airlines]] Flight 1064, a DC-8, from Los Angeles to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 4''' Jessie Willis hijacks a [[Cessna 182]] from [[Naples, Florida]] to Cuba; he returns voluntarily via Mexico on January 10, 1969; he is sentenced to 10 years for kidnapping; he is paroled on July 28, 1971.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 22''' Bill McBride hijacks a [[Cessna 336]] from [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''September 20''' [[Eastern Air Lines]] Flight 950, a [[Boeing 720]], is hijacked to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19680920-2|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''September 22''' [[Avianca]] Flight 101, a [[Boeing 727]] is hijacked after takeoff from [[Barranquilla]], [[Colombia]] and diverted to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19670922-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''September 22''' On the same day, an [[Avianca]] Flight 654, a C-54 from the same Colombian airport is hijacked to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19680922-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 6''' A Mexican-owned [[Hawker Siddeley HS 748]] is hijacked by three passengers to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19681006-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''October 23''' [[Alben Truitt]], the grandson of former U.S. Vice President [[Alben Barkley]], hijacks a [[Cessna 177]] from Key West to Cuba; he returns via Canada in February 1969; he is sentenced to 20 years for aircraft piracy and 20 years for kidnapping (to run consecutively).<ref name="Chronology" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvnews.vanderbilt.edu/program.pl?ID=446911|title=Hijacking Conviction -- Aug 13, 1969 -- NBC -- TV news: Vanderbilt Television News Archive|work=vanderbilt.edu}}</ref> * '''November 4''' Raymond Johnson hijacks [[National Airlines (1934–1980)|National Airlines]] Flight 186, a Boeing 727, from [[New Orleans]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /><ref>{{ASN accident|id=19681104-1|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''November 18''' A [[Mexicana de Aviacion]] [[Douglas DC-6|DC-6]] from Mexico is hijacked to Cuba.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19681118-0|type=Hijacking}}</ref> * '''November 23''' Five Cubans hijack a Boeing 727 from Chicago to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''November 24''' Three Cubans hijack a [[Boeing 707]] from New York to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''November 30''' Montesino Sanchez, a Cuban, hijacks a [[Boeing 720]] from Miami to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''December 5''' Eduardo Castera hijacks a Boeing 727 from Tampa to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''December 11''' Two men hijack a DC-8 from [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" />
=== 1969 === * '''January 2, 1969''' Two Americans, a man and woman, hijack a DC-8 from New York to Cuba. The hijackers, Tyrone Ellington Austin and Linda Joyce Austin, eventually returned to the US. Tyrone Ellington was killed during an altercation with police in 1971, and Linda Joyce was arrested in 1988 and spent 6 months in prison after it was discovered that she participated in the hijacking.. <ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 9''' Ronald Bohle, a 21-year-old [[Purdue University]] student, hijacks a Boeing 727 from Miami to Cuba; he returns via Canada on November 1, 1969, and is sentenced to 20 years for air piracy on July 6, 1972.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 11''' A man hijacks a 727 from [[Jacksonville, Florida]] to Cuba; he returns via Canada on May 5, 1969; he is acquitted of air piracy and kidnapping on grounds of temporary insanity.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 13''' A man unsuccessfully attempts to hijack a Convair 880 from [[Detroit]] to Cuba; he is sentenced on July 31, 1969, to 15 years for interference with a flight crew; he had a history of mental illness.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 17''' A man from the [[Dominican Republic]] hijacks a DC-8 from New York to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 24, 1969''' A man hijacks a Boeing 727 from Key West to Cuba; he was a 19-year-old [[United States Navy|Navy]] deserter who "didn't want to go to [[Vietnam]]".<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 28''' Two men successfully hijack a DC-8 from Los Angeles to Cuba; they are prison escapees.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''January 31''' Allan Sheffield hijacks a DC-8 from San Francisco to Cuba; he says he is "tired of TV dinners and tired of seeing people starve in the world".<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''February 3''' A 21-year-old student and his girlfriend attempt to hijack a plane from New York City to Cuba; when the pilot refuels in Miami, the hijackers allow the passengers to deplane; the police capture the hijackers.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''February 3''' Two Cubans hijack a 727 from [[Newark, New Jersey]], to Cuba. [[Candid Camera]] creator [[Allen Funt]] was a passenger on the flight, and because other passengers recognized him, they assumed and believed that the hijacking was a stunt for the show, despite his protestations.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''February 10''' A man born in Cuba hijacks a DC-8 from [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''February 25''' A man hijacks a DC-8 from Atlanta to Cuba; he surrenders to U.S. authorities in [[Prague]], [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|CSR]], in September 1969; he is sentenced to life imprisonment on July 7, 1970.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 6''' [[Black Panther Party|Black Panther]] Tony Bryant (d. 1999 at 60) hijacks a National Airlines plane en route from New York to Miami and directed it to Cuba. He was arrested in Cuba and spent 10 years in a Cuban prison after being suspected of being a CIA agent. The US Government pardoned Bryant after his return in 1980. His 1984 book "Hijack" described his experience in Cuban prisons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timelines.ws/countries/CUBA.HTML|title=Timeline Cuba|first=Algis|last=Ratnikas|work=timelines.ws}}</ref> [[File:JacksonvilleFLairport.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Jacksonville airport Florida]] * '''March 17''' A man hijacks an airliner from Atlanta to Cuba; he returns via Canada on November 1, 1969; he is committed to a mental institution on February 1, 1972; he is released on second 18-month furlough on December 5, 1973.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 19''' A man tries to hijack a CV-880 from [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] to Cuba; he ends up in New Orleans; charges are dismissed due to insanity.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 26''' A man hijacked a [[Delta Air Lines Flight 821]] (DC-8) from Dallas, Tex. bringing all 114 passengers to Havana, Cuba, many of which were active duty military. * '''May 5''' Jean-Pierre Charette and Alain Alard (members of the Front de Libération du Québec) successfully hijack a Boeing 727 from New York to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''May 23''' Three men born in Cuba successfully hijack a 727 from Miami to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''June 17''' A man hijacks a 707 from [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''June 22''' A man born in Cuba hijacks a DC-8 from Newark, N.J., to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''June 25''' A man successfully hijacks a DC-8 from Los Angeles to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''June 28''' A man successfully hijacks a 727 from [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]] to Cuba. He returns via Canada in November 1969; he is sentenced to 15 years for interference with a flight crew on October 6, 1970.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''July 26''' A man hijacks a DC-8 from [[El Paso, Texas]], to Cuba. He returns via Canada on November 1, 1969; he is sentenced to 50 years for aircraft piracy on September 14, 1970.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''July 31''' A man successfully hijacks a 727 from [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 5''' A man unsuccessfully tries to hijack a DC-9 from [[Philadelphia]] to Cuba; charges are dismissed on January 12, 1970; he is committed to a mental institution; he is discharged on September 15, 1971.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 14''' Two Cubans hijack a 727 from [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 29''' A Cuban hijacks a 727 from Miami to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''September 7''' A man hijacks a DC-8 from New York to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''September 10''' A [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] unsuccessfully tries to hijack a DC-8 (scheduled for [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]) to Cuba; he is committed to mental institution on January 30, 1970; he is released in December 1971.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''September 24''' A Cuban hijacks a DC-8 from [[Charleston, South Carolina]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''October 9''' A man hijacks a DC-8 from Los Angeles to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''October 21''' A man hijacks a Boeing 720 from Mexico City to Cuba. He committed suicide in Cuba on September 28, 1970.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''November 4''' Two armed men seize a [[Nicaragua]]n airliner en route from Miami to Mexico; they divert it to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''December 26''' M. Martinez (alias) hijacks a 727 from New York to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" />
== 1970s ==
=== 1970 === * '''February 16''' A man who was born in Cuba, with wife and two children, successfully hijacks a 727 from Newark to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''March 11''' A man hijacks a 727 from [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]] to Cuba; he is imprisoned in Cuba for attempting to escape; he is fatally shot escaping from prison on March 26, 1973.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''April 22''' In 1966 Ira David Meeks was diagnosed with [[paranoid schizophrenia]]. April 1970 he hijacked a plane on a sightseeing tour with his wife pulling a gun at the pilot demanding to be flown to Cuba. Meeks told Cuban authorities "he felt persecuted as a black man in America and had heard that things would be better in Cuba." Cuba suspected him of being a spy and deported him 1976. On arrival he was arrested for the hijacking by the FBI. He was freed in 1981 after spending years in jail and a mental hospital.<ref>[http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/cuba/hijacker-meeks.htm N.C. hijacker who forced plane to Cuba dies at 59] The Associated Press</ref> * '''May 25''' A man successfully hijacks a 727 from Chicago to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''July 1''' George Lopez hijacks a DC-8 from [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 2''' A man armed with a pistol and nitroglycerin hijacks [[Pan American World Airways|Pan Am]] Flight 229, [[Clipper Victor]], bound for San Juan from New York to Cuba. This was the first hijacking of the newly introduced [[Boeing 747]] to Cuba and Premiere [[Fidel Castro]] came out to Havana's [[José Martí Airport]] to see the new airliner for himself. Castro reportedly met in person with the Pan Am pilot Captain Augustus Watkins and expressed concerns over the ability of the big plane to take off safely from the small airport but was reassured by the Pan Am captain.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 19''' Three men (two born in Cuba, one born in Spain) hijack a [[Douglas DC-3|DC-3]] from Newark to Cuba (the plane's destination was San Juan).<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 20''' A man successfully hijacks a [[Douglas DC-9|DC-9]] from Atlanta to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''August 25''' TWA Flight 134 bound for Philadelphia from Las Vegas was hijacked to Cuba following a stopover in Chicago. The hijacker was a Vietnam Vet, Robert Labadie and was the first hijacker returned to the US the month following the incident. The Boeing 727, with 80 passengers and a 6-person crew, landed in a field in Pittsburgh to refuel, then proceeded on to Havana's José Martí Airport,landing at 10:21 p.m. * '''September 19''' A man successfully hijacks an [[Allegheny Airlines]] 727 from [[Pittsburgh]] to Cuba with a pistol and home made bomb. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M0McAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6VwEAAAAIBAJ&dq=it-happened%20john-place&pg=1713%2C1291774] <ref name="Chronology" /> * '''October 30''' L. Rosas hijacks a DC-8 from Miami to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''November 1''' A man born in Mexico successfully hijacks a 727 from San Diego to Cuba; he has two children with him.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''November 13''' A man hijacks an airliner from [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''December 19''' A man attempts to hijack a DC-9 from [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]] to Cuba. He is taken into custody at [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]]; he is sentenced to 5 years subject to a medical [[Psychological evaluation|mental examination]] for conveying false information about an attempt to commit air piracy.<ref name="Chronology" />
=== 1971 === * '''January 22, 1971''' A man successfully hijacks a 727 from [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], to Cuba; he would have gone to [[Algeria]], if possible.<ref name="Chronology2">[http://cuban-exile.com/doc_176-200/doc0180.html Cuban Political Violence in the United States] Disorders and terrorism, National Advisory Committee, on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals Washington: 1976. Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism Appendix 6: Chronology of incidents of terroristic, quasi-terroristic attacks, and political violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976 By Marcia McKnight Trick</ref> * '''February 4''' A man successfully hijacks a DC-9 from Chicago to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''February 25''' A man successfully hijacks a 727 from San Francisco to Cuba or Canada; he ends up in Canada; he is deported on March 8, 1971; he is sentenced to 10 years for interference with a flight crew.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''March 31''' A man born in [[Venezuela]] successfully hijacks a DC-8 from New York to Cuba; he returns to the United States via [[Bermuda]] on October 8, 1974.<ref name="Chronology2" /> [[File:Airports KEYW Nuggetboy 001.JPG|right|thumb|250px|[[Key West International Airport]] Florida]] * '''April 5''' A former Cuban hijacks a [[Cessna 402]] from Key West to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''July 11''' A Cubana de Aviación aircraft is hijacked at [[Cienfuegos]], Cuba ([[Cienfuegos Airport]]) resulting in one fatality. The two hijackers were taken down and the hijacking lasted less than one day.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''July 24''' A man born in Cuba successfully hijacks a DC-8 from Miami to Cuba, a stewardess and a passenger are wounded.<ref name="Chronology" /> * '''September 3''' A man born in Cuba, attempts to hijack a plane from Chicago to Cuba; he is sentenced to 20 years for interference with a flight crew on March 6, 1972.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''October 9''' A man forces his way aboard a 727 in Detroit and hijacks it to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''October 18''' A man born in Canada, unsuccessfully attempts to hijack a [[Boeing 737]] from [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] to Cuba; the attempt ends in [[Vancouver]]; he is deported to the United States on October 19, 1971, and is sentenced to 20 years for air piracy on May 12, 1972.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''October 25''' A man born in Puerto Rico successfully hijacks a [[Pan American World Airways]] [[Boeing 747]] from New York to Cuba; the plane was bound for San Juan.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''October 29''' A man, his two sons, and a third youth hijack an [[Eastern Airlines]] jet from [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] to Havana. They kill a ticket agent during seizure of plane.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''November 27''' Three members of the group [[Republic of New Afrika]] who had murdered a New Mexico State Policeman on November 8 hijacked [[TWA Flight 106]], a Boeing 727, from [[Albuquerque]] to Havana. Passengers were released in Tampa.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Mahr | first1=Ed | last2=McCrossen | first2=Eric | title=Trio sought in slaying seizes jetliner here | url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14187202/albuquerque_journal/ | accessdate=October 5, 2017 | work=Albuquerque Journal | date=November 28, 1971}}</ref>
=== 1972 === * '''January 7, 1972''' A man and a woman hijack a 727 from San Francisco to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''March 7''' Two men force their way aboard a Chalk's Flying Service Grumman 73 (G/A) in Miami, Florida, wounding the pilot, a mechanic, and a bystander. They hijack the plane to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''March 19''' A man and a woman successfully hijack a [[Cessna 206]] from Key West to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''May 4–6''' Michael Hansen hijacks a Boeing 737 flight from [[Salt Lake City, Utah|Salt Lake City]] to Los Angeles; he wants to go to [[Hanoi]] or Cuba; he goes to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''October 29''' Four men force their way aboard an aircraft. They kill a ticket agent, wound a ramp serviceman, and hijack a plane to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" /> * '''November 10''' Melvin C. Cale, Louis Cale, and Henry D. Jackson, Jr. successfully hijack [[Southern Airways Flight 49]] from [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] to multiple locations in the United States, including [[Cleveland, Ohio]], [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], and [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]]; [[Toronto]], [[Canada]], and finally to Cuba with $2 million in ransom (actual cash, Presidential "grant" totaled $10 million) and 10 parachutes. Co-pilot Harold is shot and wounded by the hijackers; they threaten to crash the plane into one of the [[Oak Ridge, Tennessee|Oak Ridge]] nuclear installations; at [[McCoy Air Force Base]], in [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] shoots out two tires; the hijackers force pilot William Haas to take off; the [[DC-9]] finally lands on a (partially) foam-covered runway in Havana; Jackson and Louis Cale are sentenced in Cuba to 20 years, Melvin Cale to 15 years,<ref name="Chronology2" /> then returned to the United States to face further charges.<ref>Time of Transition: The 70s, Our American Century, Time-Life Books, Alexandria, Virginia, p.134-5</ref> This incident leads to a brief treaty between the U.S. and Cuba to extradite hijackers, not renewed. Haas's story commemorated in the Reader's Digest book ''People in Peril'' <ref>Reader's Digest (author/publisher). (1983). ''People in Peril and How They Survived. We're Taking Over This Plane and We're Not Gonna Have Any Heroes!'' 573 pages.</ref>
=== 1974 === * '''December 14, 1974''' Robin Harrison charters a plane by phone. On arrival at the airport office in Tampa, he points gun at the pilot of a [[Piper PA-34 Seneca|Piper Seneca]] and demands a flight to Cuba.<ref name="Chronology2" />
=== 1978 === * ''' March 13, 1978''' Hijacker Clay Thomas hijacked [[United Flight 696]] out of San Francisco. He claimed to have a high explosive filled pipe bomb and wanted to go to Cuba. Flight 696 landed at Oakland and after the passengers and cabin crew disembarked, began fueling for the flight to Cuba. Surrounded by police cars, Thomas panicked, stopped the refueling, and forced the crew to take off.
:En route, Flight 696 landed in Denver to take on more fuel. While waiting for the fuel truck, the crew escaped the cockpit by jumping from the open cockpit windows. Without hostages, Thomas quickly surrendered to the FBI.
:The Seattle-based crew, which included Captain Alan Grout, First Officer Jack Bard, and Second Officer Luke Warfield were all injured during the escape. They subsequently recovered and returned to flight duty during the following months.
=== 1979 === * '''June 12, 1979''' [[Delta Air Lines Flight 1061]], an L-1011 piloted by Captain Vince Doda, is hijacked by Eduardo Guerra Jimenez, a former Cuban air force pilot who had hijacked a MIG jet to the United States 10 years earlier.<ref name="Chronology2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19790611-1&lang=en|title=ASN Aircraft accident Lockheed L-1011 TriStar registration unknown Havana|first=Harro|last=Ranter|work=aviation-safety.net}}</ref>
== 1980s == * '''September 13, 1980''' A [[Delta Air Lines]] from [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], bound for Atlanta, is hijacked. The pilot flew to Havana, the hijackers were removed from the plane and the flight, with 81 passengers, continued to Atlanta.<ref>[http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/hijackers/sentence-03.htm Cuban Man Gets 10 Years for Hijacking] The Associated Press</ref> * '''March 27, 1984''' William Potts hijacked a [[Piedmont Airlines]] flight originally destined to leave from Newark, N.J. and to land in Miami, Florida. Potts identified himself as Lt. Spartacus of the Black Liberation Army and forced the pilot to fly to Havana, Cuba, claiming to have explosives on the airplane. Cuban officials arrested Potts, who then served 13 years in a Cuban prison for air piracy.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/william-potts-ex-militant-who-hijacked-airliner-returns-to-us-after-30-years-in-cuba/] CBS News</ref> * '''December 31, 1984''' An American Airlines DC-10 from [[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands]] (STX) bound for New York City (JFK) is hijacked to Havana. The hijacker (Ismail La Beet), a convicted perpetrator of the [[Fountain Valley massacre]], was confirmed to be living at large in Cuba following an indeterminate amount of time spent in a Cuban prison. A documentary about him, ''The Skyjacker's Tale'', premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] in 2016. * '''March 11, 1987''' A Cubana de Aviación [[Antonov An-24|Antonov 24RV]] (''CU-T1262'') on a scheduled domestic passenger flight from [[Nueva Gerona]] ([[Rafael Cabrera Airport]]), Cuba is hijacked. The hijacker was taken down and there was one fatality.
== 1990s == * '''February 4, 1992''' Luis Rodríguez hijacks a plane from Cuba with other eight people. The plane ran out of fuel and fell to the sea near the Florida keys. There were no survivors.<ref name="hijacked" /> * '''November 15, 1993''' Alvarez Manuel & Alvaro Dominguez flew a Russian-built AN-2 biplane on a four-hour, zig-zag course to confuse Cuban radar. Guided by a U.S. Coast Guard interceptor, he landed just before dawn at Opa-Locka Airport just north of Miami.<ref name="hijacked" /> * '''June 7, 1996''' Lieutenant Colonel [[José Fernández Pupo]] hijacks a Cubana [[Antonov An-2|An-2]] with 10 passengers, flying from [[Bayamo]] to Santiago de Cuba, demanding at gunpoint to land in [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base]]. On May 29, 1997 he was declared not guilty by U.S. courts.<ref name="hijacked" /> * '''July 26, 1996''' Iberia Airlines Flight 6621 McDonnell-Douglas DC-10 flying from Madrid to Havana with 286 people aboard is forced to land in Miami by Lebanese National Saado Ibrahim, threatening the use of a bomb, later found to be fake. No one is injured.<ref name="Jordan">{{Cite web |url=http://www.localnewswatch.com/jordanfalls/stories/index.php?action=fullnews&id=105348 |title=Attempted hijackings in Cuba since 1987 |access-date=May 4, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928010438/http://www.localnewswatch.com/jordanfalls/stories/index.php?action=fullnews&id=105348 |archive-date=September 28, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * '''August 16, 1996''' Commercial pilot Adel Given Ulloa and two other workers of Aerotaxi, Leonardo Reyes and José Roberto Bello, force pilot Adolfo Pérez Pantoja to fly to the United States. The plane ran out of fuel in the [[Straits of Florida|Florida Straits]] and fell to the sea 50 km south of [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]]. They were collected by a Russian ship. The three were declared not guilty of hijacking by a court in Tampa. All remained in the U.S.<ref name="hijacked" />
== 2000s == * '''September 19, 2000''' – An [[Antonov An-2]] crashes into the sea west of Cuba. Cuban authorities said the plane was hijacked after take-off from [[Pinar del Río]].<ref>[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0009/19/bn.02.html Cuban Plane Hijacked Aired September 19, 2000] CNN transcripts</ref> * '''July 31, 2001''' – John Milo Reese steals a plane from [[Florida Keys Marathon Airport]] with the reported intention of delivering a pizza to [[Fidel Castro]] in an attempt to kidnap the Cuban leader. After crash-landing on a Cuban beach, he was returned to the United States, where he was convicted of transporting a stolen aircraft, and was sentenced to six months in jail. In a later interview, he admitted to being slightly intoxicated and having lost his bearings in the air.<ref>http://www.keynoter.com/articles/2005/05/02/columns/col02.txt Florida Keys Keynoter, Tuesday, April 26, 2005 {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> * '''August 14, 2001''' – An elderly couple attempts to hijack a plane and force the pilot to fly to Cuba. In the ensuing scuffle the plane crashed into the sea near Florida and the couple drowned.<ref>[http://www.harpers.org/Cuba.html Events Related To Cuba] Harpers Magazine</ref> * '''November 11, 2002''' – A Cuban An-2 aircraft, registration No. CU-C1086, is hijacked. The plane landed at the [[Pinar del Río]] airport before flying to Key West in Florida.<ref>[http://www.un.int/cuba/Pages/terrorismoavionetas201102-ing.htm PERMANENT MISSION OF THE REPUBLIC OF CUBA TO THE UNITED NATIONS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050829222801/http://www.un.int/cuba/Pages/terrorismoavionetas201102-ing.htm |date=August 29, 2005 }}</ref> * '''March 19, 2003''' – Six men, some armed with knives, take control of a Cuban state airline plane as it heads to Havana from Cuba's [[Isle of Youth]]. [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] fighter jets intercepted the DC-3 plane, run by Cuban state airline Aerotaxi, shortly before it reached Florida late on Wednesday evening. The U.S. jets then escorted the plane to Key West's airport, where the suspects surrendered without incident.<ref>[http://www.cubanet.org/CNews/y03/mar03/20e2.htm Cuba's sweep of dissidents intensifies with at least 55 detained] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051102013219/http://www.cubanet.org/CNews/y03/mar03/20e2.htm |date=November 2, 2005 }} Yahoo News</ref> * '''March 31, 2003''' – A Cuban airliner is successfully hijacked to Key West with 32 people on board.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schelzig|first1=Erik|title=Man Who Hijacked Cuban Plane Surrenders|url=https://www.ourmidland.com/news/article/Man-Who-Hijacked-Cuban-Plane-Surrenders-7137172.php|website=Midland Daily News|publisher=Midland Daily News}}</ref> * '''April 1, 2003''' – A man carrying two grenades hijacks a Cuban domestic airliner demanding that it fly to the United States; it landed in Havana due to insufficient fuel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cuban plane hijacking suspect held|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/americas/04/01/cuba.hijacking/|website=CNN|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Cuba}} * [[Aircraft hijacking]] * [[Cuba-United States relations]] * [[Cubana Flight 455]] * [[List of United States citizens granted political asylum in Cuba]]

{{MTV}} [[MTV]], the first and most popular [[music]] [[television network]] in the [[United States|U.S.]] has a long history of hosting live music events in which [[awards]] are handed out. Along with MTV's related [[List of MTV channels|channels around the world]], the network produces over 20 award shows annually. This '''list of MTV award shows''' links to further information about each of these shows.
== MTV award shows in the U.S. == ''NOTE: Includes all MTV networks.'' *[[MTV Video Music Award]] (1984~present) *[[MTV Movie & TV Awards]] (1992~present) *[[MTVU|MTVU Woodie Awards]] (2004~present) *[[MTV Fandom Awards]] (2014~present)
== MTV award shows around the world == ===Current shows=== *[[MTV Europe Music Award]] *[[MTV Millennial Awards]] *[[MTV Video Music Awards Japan]] *[[MTV Africa Music Awards]] *TIM MTV Awards

===Renaissance fairs=== * [[Alabama Renaissance Faire]], [[Alabama]] * [[Arizona Renaissance Festival]], [[Arizona]] * [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]], [[Wisconsin]] * [[Carolina Renaissance Festival]], North Carolina * [[Georgia Renaissance Festival]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] * [[Kansas City Renaissance Festival]], [[Kansas]] * [[Kentucky Highland Renaissance Festival]], [[Kentucky]] * [[King Richard's Faire]], [[Massachusetts]] * [[Louisiana Renaissance Festival]], [[Louisiana]] * [[Maryland Renaissance Festival]], [[Maryland]] * [[Michigan Renaissance Festival]], [[Michigan]] * [[Middlefaire]], [[Texas]] * [[Minnesota Renaissance Festival]], [[Minnesota]] * [[New York Renaissance Faire]], [[New York (state)|New York]] * [[Ohio Renaissance Festival]], [[Ohio]] * [[Pennsylvania Renaissance Faire]], Pennsylvania * [[Pittsburgh Renaissance Festival]], Pennsylvania * [[Renaissance Pleasure Faire of Southern California]], [[California]] * [[Scarborough Renaissance Festival]], Texas * [[Sterling Renaissance Festival]], New York * [[Texas Renaissance Festival]], Texas * [[Virginia Renaissance Faire (1996-1999)|Virginia Renaissance Faire]], Virginia * [[Wicked Winter Renaissance Faire]], [[New Jersey]]
===Other=== * [[1940's World War II Era Ball]], [[Colorado]] * Colonial Faire (http://www.rileysfarm.com/faire) Oak Glen, California * [[Indiana Territory Festival]], [[Indiana]] * [[Spirit of Vincennes Rendezvous]], Indiana * [[Victorian Day in Historic Grand Ledge]], Michigan
