revision.comment: Reformat 4 archive links. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{short description| }} [[File:Faraday xmas detail.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.25|[[Michael Faraday]] delivering one of the British [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]] in 1856.]] Recurrent series of prestigious [[public lecture]]s are presented in various countries. {{TOC limit|2}}
==General==
===Australia=== * The prestigious [[Errol Solomon Meyers Memorial Lecture]], held annually at the [[University of Queensland]] in Brisbane.
===Canada=== * The [[Massey Lectures]] are held at and sponsored by [[Massey College]] at the [[University of Toronto]] annually * The [[Watts Lectures]] are held several times each year at the [[University of Toronto Scarborough]]
===Denmark=== *The [[Hans Christian Ørsted#Legacy|H.C. Ørsted Lectureship]] held at and sponsored by The [[Technical University of Denmark]], annually *Public Lectures in Science (In Danish: Offentlige Foredrag i Naturvidenskab) sponsored by Faculty of Science and Technology, [[Aarhus University]], and held in Vejle, Horsens, Herning and Aarhus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scitech.au.dk/foredrag/|title=Offentlige foredrag i Naturvidenskab, Aarhus Universitet - Livestream og live|website=scitech.au.dk}}</ref>
===India=== *[[Vasant Vyakhyanmala]] is a traditional annual spring lecture series held in [[Pune]], India, for the last 140 years and hosted by [[Vaktruttvottejak Sabha]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Vasant Vyakhyanmala to start from April 21|url=http://www.sakaaltimes.com/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=4714231410731082713&SectionId=5171561142064258099&SectionName=Pune&NewsDate=20110419&NewsTitle=Vasant%20Vyakhyanmala%20to%20start%20from%20April%2021|accessdate=9 December 2014|agency=sakaltimes|issue=19 April 2011|publisher=sakal news papers|date=19 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Month-long spring lecture series that has been a tradition for centuries in Pune will be held till May 20.|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/pune/report-vasant-vyakhyanmala-a-century-old-lecture-series-kicks-off-in-pune-1980780|accessdate=9 December 2014|agency=dna|publisher=dna}}</ref>
* NITI (National Institute for Transforming India), India lectures series: Transforming India<ref>{{cite web|url=http://niti.gov.in/content/niti-lectures-transforming-india|title=Lecture 3: Competitiveness Of Nations & States - New Insights - NITI Aayog, (National Institution for Transforming India), Government of India|website=niti.gov.in}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== * [[Gresham College]] gives free public lectures since it was founded in 1597 * The [[Reith Lecture]]s, broadcast annually on the [[BBC]], founded in honour of [[John Reith, 1st Baron Reith|Lord Reith]] * The [[Romanes Lecture]]s, on "any topic in the Arts, Science, or Literature", given annually at the [[University of Oxford]] founded by [[George Romanes]] * The [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]] have presented scientific ideas to young people in an entertaining manner since 1825.
===United States=== * [[ATC Lecture Series|The Art, Technology, and Culture (ATC) Lecture Series]], at [[University of California, Berkeley]] in Berkeley, CA * The [[Charles Eliot Norton Lectures]] at Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA * Distinctive Voices, sponsored by the [[National Academy of Sciences]], presents lectures on a wide range of scientific and technical topics at the Beckman Center in Irvine, CA and the Jonsson Center in Woods Hole, MA<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/programs/distinctive-voices/ |title=Distinctive Voices Home |publisher=Nasonline.org |date= |accessdate=2013-06-17}}</ref> * The [[Morgenthau Lectures]], at the [[Carnegie Council]] in New York
==Social and political== ===United States=== * [[Landon Lecture Series]] at [[Kansas State University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ome.ksu.edu/lectures/landon/index.html |title=Landon Lecture Series - Home Page - KSU-OME |publisher=Ome.ksu.edu |date=2004-07-31 |accessdate=2013-06-17}}</ref> * Whizin Center Public Lecture Series at the [[American Jewish University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wcce.ajula.edu/Content/forms/pls2009.asp?CID=1137&t=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228063147/http://wcce.ajula.edu/Content/forms/pls2009.asp?CID=1137&t=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 December 2008|title=2OO9 PUBLIC LECTURE SERIES - WHIZIN CENTER FOR CONTINUING EDUCATION ( WCCE ) American Jewish University ( AJULA ) formerly University of Judaism ( Form )|date=28 December 2008|publisher=}}</ref>
==Aeronautics and astronautics== ===United States=== * Evolution of Flight Lecture Series from [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]] (AIAA)
==Computer science== ===Canada=== * UBC CS Distinguished Lecture Series<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.ubc.ca/events/seminars/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060808213204/http://www.cs.ubc.ca/events/seminars/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 August 2006|title=UBC CPSC - Events and Seminars|date=8 August 2006|publisher=}}</ref>
===Greece=== * Distinguished Lecturer Series - Leon The Mathematician] at School of Informatics, [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Leon the Mathematician|url=https://www.csd.auth.gr/en/news/lectures/|publisher=Aristotle University of Thessaloniki – School of Informatics|date=28 March 2017}}</ref>
===United States=== * CDS Lecture Series at Intelligent Servosystems Laboratory, Institute for Systems Research at [[University of Maryland, College Park]] * MURL Lecture Series at Multi-University/Research Laboratory (MURL) as a group of institutions:<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040331171652/http://murl.microsoft.com/ Seminar series: recently added lectures], Multi-University/Research Laboratory, March 31, 2004.</ref> ** School of Computer Science, [[Carnegie Mellon University]]; ** Laboratory for Computer Science, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]; ** [[Microsoft Research]]; ** School of Engineering, [[Stanford University]]; ** Dept. of Computer Science, [[University of Washington]]; and ** [[Xerox]] [[Palo Alto Research Center]].
==History and humanities==
===United Kingdom=== * [[Caird Medal]] lecture series at the [[National Maritime Museum]] * [[E. A. Lowe Lectures]], given triennially at [[Corpus Christi College, Oxford|Corpus Christi College]], [[University of Oxford]], on [[palaeography]] * [[Ford Lectures]], given annually at [[Oxford University]] on British history * [[Lyell Lectures]], given annually at [[Oxford University]] on the [[history of the book]] or [[bibliography]] * [[McKenzie Lectures]], given annually at [[Oxford University]] on the [[history of the book]], scholarly editing, [[textual criticism]], or [[bibliography]] * [[Panizzi Lectures]], given annually at the [[British Library]] on a topic in [[bibliography]] or [[History of the book|book history]] * [[Sandars Lectures]], given annually at [[Cambridge University]] on a topic in [[bibliography]] or [[History of the book|book history]] * [[Lees Knowles Lecturer|Lees Knowles Lectures]], given annually military history at Trinity College, Cambridge * Raleigh Lectures on History at the [[British Academy]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/events/series.html |title=Information about the British Academy's Lecture series - British Academy |publisher=Britac.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-06-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625095054/http://www.britac.ac.uk/events/series.html |archive-date=2008-06-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> London, England, * [[Black History for Action]] at Lambeth Town Hall, London, England. * Keynes Lectures in Economics at the [[British Academy]], London, England.
===United States=== * Annual History Lecture series from [[University of Washington Alumni Association]] (UWAA). * [[Chicago Humanities Festival]] * [[James Ford Bell Lecture]] series at the [[University of Minnesota]] * [[Jefferson Lecture]], annual honorary lecture sponsored by the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] * [[Massey Lectures (Harvard University)]] * W. A. Hammond Lecture on the American Tradition, [[Miami University]] since 1962 ===Hungary=== * [[Eötvös József Lecture]]
===The Netherlands=== * [[Nexus Lectures]] since 1994 <ref>https://nexus-instituut.nl/en/activities/?event_type%5B0%5D=lecture#filter</ref>
==Journalism and media studies== ===United States=== * [[Robert C. Vance Distinguished Lecture Series]] at [[Central Connecticut State University]]
== Law == ===United Kingdom=== * [[Hamlyn Lectures]]
==Mathematics and mathematical sciences== ===United Kingdom=== * Sir David Wallace Lecture Series at [[Loughborough University]]
===United States=== * Spring Lecture Series at [[University of Arkansas]]
==Neurosciences and mind/brain sciences== ===Australia=== * The Melbourne Neuroscience Public Lecture Series at The Melbourne Neuroscience Institute, University of Melbourne
===Canada=== * Treva Glazebrook Lecture Series at [[University of Western Ontario]]
===United States=== * CSHL Adult Lectures at [[Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory]] * Contemporary Neurology and Neuroscience Evening Lecture Series at Department of Neurology, [[University of California, Irvine]] * Cognitive Neuroscience Lecture Series at Center for Neural Science|the Center for Neural Science, [[New York University]] * Duke Neurobiology Lecture Series at Department of Neurobiology, [[Duke University Medical Center]] * Frontiers in Neuroscience Lecture Series by the Graduate Program in Neuroscience, [[Emory University]] * Gardner Murphy Memorial Lecture Series by [[American Society for Psychical Research|the American Society for Psychical Research]] * HHMI's Neuroscience Lecture Series at Howard Hughes Medical Institute<ref>{{cite web|title=Neuroscience|url=https://www.hhmi.org/biointeractive/neuroscience-collection|publisher=HHMI BioInteractive}}</ref> * IHF Distinguished Lecture Series on Brain, Learning and Memory at Irvine Health Foundation * Interdisciplinary Seminar at Oklahoma Center for Neuroscience (OCNS) * Distinguished Lecturer Series at [[UC Davis]] [[M.I.N.D. Institute]] * Mind, Brain and Behavior Distinguished Lecture Series at Center for Cognitive Neurosciences, [[Duke University]] * Mind/Brain Lecture Series at Swartz Foundation * MNIF Public Lecture Series at Montana Neuroscience Institute Foundation * Neuroscience Lecture Series at [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] * NRC Lecture Series at Neuroscience Research Center, [[University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston]] * NUIN Lecture Series at the Northwestern University Institute for Neuroscience * Pinkel Endowed Lecture Series at Institute for Research in Cognitive Science, [[University of Pennsylvania]] * Wyeth Distinguished Lecture Series in Behavioral Neuroscience at [[Rutgers University]] * Yerkes Neuroscience Lecture Series by Neuroscience Division, [[Yerkes National Primate Research Center]]
==Physics== ===Canada=== * Perimeter Institute's Public Lecture Series at [[Perimeter Institute]]
===United Kingdom=== * [[Sir Nevill Mott]] Lecture Series at [[Loughborough University]]
===United States=== * Fermilab Lecture Series at [[Fermilab]] * [[Henry Norris Russell Lectureship]] before the [[American Astronomical Society]] * [[National Radio Astronomy Observatory#Jansky Prize|Jansky Lectureship]] before the [[National Radio Astronomy Observatory]] * Leon Pape Memorial Lecture Series at [[California State University at Los Angeles]] * Lyman Parratt Lecture Series at [[Cornell University]] * Theodore von Kármán Lecture Series at [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL) * [[Richtmyer Memorial Award]] Lectureship, by the [[American Association of Physics Teachers]]
==Medical sciences== ===Italy=== * Giuseppe Bigi Memorial Lecture Series, Milan<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.giuseppebigi.it|title=Associazione Giuseppe Bigi - Associazione Giuseppe Bigi|website=www.giuseppebigi.it}}</ref>
==Science== ===Spain=== * [[Program ConCiencia]] at the [[University of Santiago de Compostela]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Lecture series| ]] [[Category:Lists of events|Public lecture series]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/24.159.60.138|24.159.60.138]] ([[User talk:24.159.60.138|talk]]): WP:NOTBROKEN. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Royal wedding|the 1951 MGM musical|Royal Wedding}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2018}} [[File:The marriage procession of Dara Shikoh - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|The [[Mughal emperors|Mughal Emperor]] [[Shah Jahan]] attends the marriage procession of his eldest son [[Dara Shikoh]]. Mughal-Era [[fireworks]] were utilized to brighten the night throughout the wedding ceremony.]]
A '''royal wedding''' is a [[marriage ceremony]] involving members of a [[royal family]]. Weddings involving senior members of the royal family are often seen as important occasions of state and attract significant national and international attention. The following is a list of notable royal weddings:
== 19th century == ===Russian Empire=== * [[Wedding of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna|26 November 1895]]: [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]], the last [[Emperor of All Russia|Emperor of Russia]], was married to [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Feodorovna]] at the [[Grand Church of the Winter Palace]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|10 February 1840]]: [[Queen Victoria]], only daughter of [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn]], and successor of [[William IV of the United Kingdom|King William IV]], was married to [[Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], Duke of Saxony, at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]]. * [[Wedding of Prince George, Duke of York, and Princess Mary of Teck|6 July 1893]]: [[George V|Prince George, Duke of York]], second son of King [[Edward VII]], was married to [[Mary of Teck|Princess Victoria Mary of Teck]] at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]].
== 20th century == ===Belgium=== * [[Wedding of Prince Philippe and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz|4 December 1999]]: [[Philippe of Belgium|Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant]], eldest child and successor to [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]], was married to [[Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] at the [[Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula]].
===Greece=== * [[Wedding of Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece, and Marie-Chantal Miller|1 July 1995]]: [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]], eldest son and second child of [[Constantine II of Greece|King Constantine II]], was married to [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal Miller]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York, and Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|26 April 1923]]: [[George VI|Prince Albert, Duke of York]], second son of King [[George V]] and successor to [[Edward VIII|King Edward VIII]], was married to [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten|20 November 1947]]: [[Elizabeth II|Princess Elizabeth]], eldest daughter and successor of King [[George VI]], was married to [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Anne and Mark Phillips|14 November 1973]]: [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Anne]], only daughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Mark Phillips|Captain Mark Phillips]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer|29 July 1981]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson|23 July 1986]]: [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], second son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sarah, Duchess of York|Sarah Ferguson]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones|19 June 1999]]: [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], youngest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Sophie Rhys-Jones]] at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]].
== 21st century == ===Bhutan=== * [[Wedding of Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Jetsun Pema|13 October 2011]]: [[Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck]], King of Bhutan, was married to [[Jetsun Pema]] at the [[Punakha Dzong]] in [[Punakha|Punakha, Bhutan]].
===Denmark=== * [[Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson|14 May 2004]]: [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark]], eldest son of [[Margrethe II of Denmark]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Elizabeth Donaldson]] at the [[Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)|Church of Our Lady]], [[Copenhagen]].
===Luxembourg=== * [[Wedding of Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, and Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy|20 October 2012]]: [[Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume]], eldest son of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Countess Stephanie de Lannoy]] at the [[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]].
===Monaco=== * [[Wedding of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Charlene Wittstock|1 July 2011]]: [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Albert II]], [[Monarchy of Monaco|Sovereign Prince]] of Monaco, was married to [[Charlene, Princess of Monaco|Charlene Lynette Wittstock]] at the [[Prince's Palace of Monaco]].
===Norway=== * [[Wedding of Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway, and Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby|25 August 2001]]: [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon of Norway]], only son of King [[Harald V of Norway]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mette-Marit, Crown Princess of Norway|Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby]] at the [[Oslo Cathedral]].
===Spain=== * [[Wedding of Prince Felipe and Letizia Ortiz|22 May 2004]]: [[Felipe VI of Spain|Prince Felipe of Asturias]], only son of [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], was married to [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Letizia Ortiz]] at the [[Almudena Cathedral]] at [[Royal Palace of Madrid]], [[Madrid]].
===Sweden=== * [[Wedding of Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and Daniel Westling|19 June 2010]]: [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden]], eldest daughter and heir apparent of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland|Daniel Westling]] at the [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Madeleine and Christopher O'Neill|8 June 2013]]: [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland|Princess Madeleine of Sweden]], youngest child of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Christopher O'Neill]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church. * [[Wedding of Prince Carl Philip and Sofia Hellqvist|13 June 2015]]: [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Prince Carl Philip]], Only son of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Sofia Hellqvist]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church.
===Tonga=== * [[Wedding of Crown Prince Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua|12 July 2012]]: [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala]], Crown Prince of Tonga, was married to [[Sinaitakala Fakafanua]] at the Centennial Church in [[Nukuʻalofa]], Tonga.
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles|9 April 2005]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla Parker Bowles]] at [[Windsor Guildhall]]. * [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|29 April 2011]]: [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], second grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], elder son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is second in line to the throne, was married to [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle|19 May 2018]]: [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]], third grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is sixth in line to the throne, was married to [[Meghan, Duchess of Sussex|Meghan Markle]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank|12 October 2018]]: [[Princess Eugenie]], third granddaughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger daughter of [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]] and [[Sarah Ferguson]] is ninth in line to the throne, was married to [[Jack Brooksbank]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.britishpathe.com/workspace.php?id=10826&view=list The Royal Weddings Collection - Archived newsreels of British Royal Weddings] *[http://www.itnsource.com/specials/royalengagement Royal wedding footage]
{{Wedding}}
[[Category:Royal weddings]] [[Category:Lists of events|Royal weddings]] [[Category:Royalty-related lists|Weddings]]

page.title: List of science and engineering blunders

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
This is a '''list of engineering blunders''', i.e., gross errors or mistakes resulting from grave lack of proper consideration, such as stupidity, confusion, carelessness, or culpable ignorance,<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/blunder Blunder], Dictionary.com. ''[[Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary]]'' (accessed: February 04, 2009).</ref> which resulted in notable incidents. <!-- Please list here only the incidents which are * notable * have a Wikipedia article or section * described as blunders in multiple valid sources --> *[[Fort Montgomery (Lake Champlain)]] was sometimes referred to as "Fort Blunder", because the first version of the U.S. fort was inadvertently built on the Canadian side of the border. * The [[NASA]] [[Mars Climate Orbiter]], launched in 1998, burned up in the Martian atmosphere. A mixup between metric and [[U.S. customary unit|US Standard]] measurements in the controlling software caused the spacecraft to miss its intended 140–150 km altitude above Mars during orbit insertion, instead entering the Martian atmosphere at about 57 km. * The NASA [[Genesis (spacecraft)|Genesis]] mission was an attempt to sample particles from the solar wind. It successfully collected a sample and returned to Earth. However at the last moment the landing parachute failed to open and the return capsule smashed into the ground at high speed, contaminating the samples. The parachute failure was traced to an [[Genesis (spacecraft)#Mishap_Investigation_Board_(MIB)|accelerometer installed backwards]]. * The Quebec bridge disaster. * [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)]] * [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] caused by a faulty blowout preventer.
==See also== *[[List of disasters]] for aircraft/rail/shipwreck disasters *[[Catastrophic failure#Structural_failure|Catastrophic failure]] Structural failures *[[Space accidents and incidents]] ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20140717230517/http://blunderingboffins.altervista.org/ Drunk photons and the myth of the electromagnetic vorticity]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Engineering Blunders}} [[Category:Lists of events]] [[Category:Science-related lists]] [[Category:Error]]

revision.comment: [[WP:GenFixes]] on, 3+ incoming mainspace links, removed orphan tag using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Marcy Blum''' is an American author, event planner and owner of Marcy Blum Associates in [[New York City]].
== Education == Blum is a graduate of [[The Culinary Institute of America]] and began her career in the restaurant business, later creating a segue into the then developing field of [[event planning]].<ref name=nys1>Swerdloff, Alexis ''[http://www.nysun.com/article/7482?page_no=1 What Do Padma Lakshmi and Kyra Sedgwick Have in Common? Their Wedding Planner,] [[New York Sun]]'', January 11, 2005</ref> In 1986<ref>Mallozzi, Vincent M.; Gettleman, Jeffrey ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/24/fashion/24planner.html?pagewanted=1&ref=fashion Taming the Runaway Wedding Planner,] [[The New York Times]]'', June 24, 2007</ref> she became one of the first in the industry to develop the vocation into a successful career<ref name="nys1"/>
== Career == Blum has been a guest on the ''[[CBS Morning Show]]'', ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]'', ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' and ''[[The Nate Berkus Show]].''{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://weddingmarketnews.com/marcy_blum/|title=Interview with Wedding Planner Marcy Blum – Wedding Market|website=weddingmarketnews.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
Among her clients are [[Billy Joel]] and [[Katie Lee Joel]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6874808/jimmy-iovine-liberty-ross-wedding-gift-picks|title=Jimmy Iovine & Liberty Ross Wedding Gift Picks - Billboard|author=|date=|work=Billboard}}</ref> [[Kevin Bacon]] and [[Kyra Sedgwick]], [[Salman Rushdie]] and [[Padma Lakshmi]], [[Colin Hanks]] and Samantha Bryant, [[LeBron James|Lebron James]] and Savannah James,<ref name="Williams">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/15/fashion/jennifer-aniston-justin-theroux-how-celebrities-keep-their-weddings-a-secret.html|title=How Celebrities Keep Their Weddings a Secret|last=Williams|first=Alex|date=2015-08-15|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> [[George Soros]] and Tomiko Soros,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-soros-wedding-idUSBRE98J0XZ20130922|title=Billionaire Soros weds consultant in third marriage|date=2013-09-22|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> The [[Rockefeller family]], [[Nate Berkus]] and [[Jeremiah Brent]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/nate-berkus-marries-jeremiah-brent|title=Nate Berkus Marries Jeremiah Brent|website=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> and [[Andre Iguodala]] and Christina Iguodala.<ref name="nys1"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pagesix.com/2015/08/10/nba-finals-mvp-ties-the-knot/|title=NBA Finals MVP ties the knot|last=Smith|first=Emily|website=Page Six|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20773192,00.html|title=Couple Injured in Boston Marathon Bombing to Marry in Dream Wedding|website=people.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> She was also the planner of [[The Knot Inc.|The Knot]]'s "Dream Wedding" in 2014 of Boston Marathon bombing survivors, Rebekah Gregory and Pete DiMartino.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20803009,00.html|title=Couple Injured in Boston Marathon Bombing Weds|website=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> ''[[New York magazine|New York]]'' magazine described Blum as a "desired wedding planner to the wealthy and famous."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/06/list-of-utterly-impractical-celebrity-weddings.html|title=A List of Utterly Impractical Celebrity Weddings -- The Cut|author=|date=|work=The Cut}}</ref>
''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue Magazine]]'' named Blum one of the top wedding planners in the world by,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com/13405286/best-wedding-planners-list-database-around-the-world/|title=''Vogue''{{'}}s Ultimate Wedding Planner Master List|last=Rees|first=Samantha|website=Vogue|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/wedding/planning/g6965/best-wedding-planners/|title=Bazaar's Little Black Book: The Top Wedding Planners in the U.S.|date=2016-03-16|website=Harper's Bazaar|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> and [[Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia|Martha Stewart Weddings]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.marthastewartweddings.com/381413/top-wedding-planners#381269|title=64 Top Wedding Planners|website=Martha Stewart Weddings|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
Blum has written and contributed to many articles, including ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name="Williams"/> ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymag/features/23785/index1.html|title=The High-End Party: Gilded to Perfection|website=NYMag.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> The Knot,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theknot.com/content/3-expert-planning-tips-from-celeb-wedding-stylist-marcy-blum|title=3 Expert Planning Tips from Celeb Wedding Stylist Marcy Blum|website=theknot.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> ''[[Brides (magazine)|Brides]]'' magazine, ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', ''Modern Bride'', ''[[InStyle]]'', and ''[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]''.
She coauthored, with Laura Kaiser, two books, ''Wedding Planning for Dummies'' and ''Wedding Kit for Dummies''.<ref name="nys1" />
==Personal== Marcy is the sister of American author and journalist [[Howard Blum]].
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == *''[http://nymag.com/guides/holidays/23785/index1.html The High-End Holiday Party: Gilded to Perfection]'', a guide to dining room Décor by Marcy Blum, published in ''[[New York Magazine|New York Magazine's]]'' 2006 holiday guide *[http://nymag.com/urban/guides/bestofny/services/BONY2001_services_wedding_planner.htm Marcy Blum's company listing] in ''[[New York Magazine]]''
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blum, Marcy}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:Culinary Institute of America alumni]] [[Category:Event planners]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Maxine Lewis | image = Maxine_Lewis_-_Producer,_Talent_Scout.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = Harlem, New York City, New York | birth_place = | residence = Bronx, New York | nationality = United States | education = | occupation = Entertainment Producer | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Maxine Lewis''' is a producer, talent scout, and event planner for Harlem's Amateur Night (Showtime at the Apollo). She was [[Percy Sutton]]'s spokeswoman.<ref name="nydailynews">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/money/showdown-apollo-african-heritage-network-city-tv-rights-article-1.786714|publisher=nydailynews.com|title=SHOWDOWN AT THE APOLLO AFRICAN HERITAGE NETWORK VS. INNER CITY FOR TV RIGHTS - NY Daily News|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> <ref name="dailypress">{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/2001-10-13/news/0110130243_1_apollo-cherry-audition|publisher=articles.dailypress.com|title=Yard Worker To Appear On 'Apollo' - tribunedigital-dailypress|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Percy Sutton was a Harlem leader and co-founder of the [[Inner City Broadcasting Corporation]]. The Inner City group was founded in 1970. It was founded by a group of prominent African-American New Yorkers, such as [[Clarence Benjamin Jones]], [[Hal Jackson]], [[Carl McCall]], [[Wilbert Tatum]], [[David Dinkins]], [[Betty Shabazz]], and other shareholders that were active in business, community civic involvements and development. Percy Sutton was a long term Manhattan Borough president and was a high-ranking black elected official in New York City. He was a civil rights lawyer, an entrepreneur and freedom rider.<ref name="dnainfo">{{cite web|url=https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20091228/manhattan/percy-sutton-dies-leaving-harlem-city-mourning|publisher=dnainfo.com|title=Percy Sutton Dies, Leaving Harlem and the City in Mourning - Manhattan - DNAinfo New York|accessdate=2017-03-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304040320/https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20091228/manhattan/percy-sutton-dies-leaving-harlem-city-mourning|archivedate=2017-03-04|df=}}</ref> The Inner City Broadcasting Corporation bought WLIB-AM, one of the city's first African American owned radio stations. Maxine Lewis starting working for Percy Sutton in the early 80s. Sutton produced It's Showtime at the Apollo, a syndicated, music television show first broadcast on September 12, 1987.
She has worked for the Apollo theatre for decades as a producer for [[Showtime at the Apollo]], and Apollo Kids at the [[Apollo Theater]] in Harlem.<ref name="baltimoresun">{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-08-21/features/1998233101_1_apollo-kids-sing-loud-harlem-theater|publisher=articles.baltimoresun.com|title=Tiara Shahid | 'Showtime at the Apollo' begins here Talent: Children audition at Reisterstown Road Plaza for a chance to appear at the famed Harlem theater. - tribunedigital-baltimoresun|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> She has been an organizer for over 21 years for the 154/153 streets' Extended Family Reunion in Harlem, an event that brings residents from the neighborhood and residents that used to live in the area in July of each year. <ref name="ny">{{cite web|url=https://aging.ny.gov/SeniorCitizensDay/2015Honorees/Bronx.cfm|publisher=aging.ny.gov|title=NYSOFA - News - Senior Citizens Day 2015 - Bronx County|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
==Early life== She was born and raised in [[Harlem]], [[New York City]].
==Career== Maxine Lewis is a Special Events Producer for Diamonds in the Rough Independent Entertainment from 1986 to till the present (31 years).
[[Percy Sutton]] was the founder of Inner City Broadcasting Corporation. Which bought the Apollo Theatre in 1981. They rescued the Apollo Theatre from bankruptcy Court. The theatre was refurbished. She served as Percy Sutton's Executive Assistant for 19 years.
In 1992, Maxine organized and produced a memorial tribute for tap dancer [[Charles Coles]] known as Charles "Honi" Coles at the Apollo Theatre. She began working for Inner City Broadcasting Corporation in 1982. In 1984 she became the talent coordinator for amateur segments for Showtime at the Apollo and later segment producer for "Apollo Kids" segments for over 14 years. She traveled across the country looking for talent to be showcased.<ref name="dailypress2">{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1997-10-23/features/9710220201_1_gee-puff-daddy-amateur-night|publisher=articles.dailypress.com|title=Showtime At The Apollo - tribunedigital-dailypress|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Some well known artists that she showcased were: [[Lyfe Jennings]], [[Jermaine Paul]], [[Ne-Yo]], [[Jazmine Sullivan]], [[Lauryn Hill|Lauren Hill]], [[Canton Jones]], [[Jessica Care Moore]], and more. She has a featured segment on 90.3 WHCR FM radio for Street Corner Resources giving information and updates about resources and activities for adults.<ref name="ny">{{cite web|url=https://aging.ny.gov/SeniorCitizensDay/2015Honorees/Bronx.cfm|publisher=aging.ny.gov|title=NYSOFA - News - Senior Citizens Day 2015 - Bronx County|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> She has been a community volunteer serving food for years for Thanksgiving and Christmas at the [[National Action Network]] in Harlem. She is a member of Perfecting Faith Church in Freeport, Long Island, where she utilizes her skills for community service in special events organizing and public relations work.
==Awards== 2015 - Senior Citizen's Day by the New York State Office for the Aging for her community work honored for Community Service.
2015 - Senator Díaz of the Bronx, New York City presents a Senior Citizen of the Year proclamation to Maxine Lewis <ref name="nysenate">{{cite web|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/newsroom/articles/ruben-diaz/senator-d%C3%ADaz-presents-proclamation-honoring-mrs-maxine-lewis-senior|publisher=nysenate.gov|title=Senator Díaz presents a proclamation honoring Mrs. Maxine Lewis as Senior Citizen of the Year, along with Lt. Governor Kathy Hochul, Tuesday, May 5, 2015, Albany, NY | NY State Senate|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
2014 - Fannie Lou Hamer Honoree: for her work at the National Action Network National Crisis Manager (North Jersey Chapter)<ref name="eurweb">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurweb.com/2014/04/inaugural-fannie-lue-hamer-awards-take-place-april-26-2014/#|publisher=eurweb.com|title=Inaugural Fannie Lou Hamer Awards Take Place April 26, 2014 | EURweb|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lewis, Maxine}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:American producers]] [[Category:Community development]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:Women television producers]] [[Category:Event planners]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2011}} A '''news bureau''' is an office for gathering or distributing [[news]]. Similar terms are used for specialized bureaux, often to indicate geographic location or scope of coverage: a ‘Tokyo bureau’ refers to a given news operation's office in [[Tokyo]]; 'foreign bureau' is a generic term for a news office set up in a country other than the primary operations center; a ‘Washington bureau’ is an office, typically located in [[Washington, D.C.]], that covers news related to national politics in the [[United States]]. The person in charge of a news bureau is often called the bureau chief.
The term is distinct from a news desk, which refers to the editorial function of assigning reporters and other staff, and otherwise coordinating, news stories, and sometimes the physical desk where that occurs, but without regard to the geographic location or overall operation of the news organization. For example, a foreign bureau is located in a foreign country and refers to all creative and administrative operations that take place there, whereas a foreign desk describes only editorial functions and may be located anywhere, possibly as an organizational unit within the news organization's home office.
==Operation of news bureaux== A news bureau is traditionally operated out of an office by a single news outlet such as a radio, television, or newspaper news program. A single news company such as [[CNN]] or [[NPR]] may use a single bureau and office staff for all of its programs, and even those of [[subsidiary]] or other affiliated companies. For convenience, to save money and space, and to ensure the availability of necessary services (such as video feeds and studios), different companies may share an office space or co-locate at a single office building. [[News agencies]] may also operate news bureaux, and major public relations sources (such as governments, large companies, or advocacy groups) may operate news bureaux of their own to create, rather than simply report, news stories.
==History of news bureaux== <!-- ===Origin=== insert content here -->
===Decline===
Traditional [[news media]], particularly [[television news]] and [[newspapers]], have cut the number and size of news bureaux in recent decades for several reasons. They face declining profitability due to increasing competition from Internet news sources, and therefore have less money to spend on news-gathering.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2007-11-12|title=NBC Says Viewers Won’t Notice Cuts in News Staff|author=Jaques Steinberg|date=October 20, 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/20/business/media/20nbc.html}}</ref>
Newspapers rely increasingly on cooperative arrangements with counterparts elsewhere, and often will accept stories from their sister organizations rather than investigating stories themselves. Similarly, smaller newspapers may formally affiliate to sponsor cooperative bureaux that operate as [[press pool]]s to serve more than one news organization (and sometimes a large number of organizations) from a single office. When news sources combine operations following a [[merger]] or other [[Consolidation (business)|business consolidation]], the surviving company often combines or eliminates redundant bureaux. Growing [[multiculturalism]] has facilitated this process: rather than demanding a reporter from their own country or locale who has been sent on assignment, news audiences have come to tolerate or even expect to see stories in remote locations covered by people who live locally; this empowers the audience to make their own judgments about any apparent cultural difference between themselves and the news subjects, rather than leaving the function of cultural interpretation entirely up to the reporter.
The often-criticized practice of [[parachute journalism]] allows [[News media]] to cover stories remotely using journalists who are generalists rather than more specialized field experts. Rather than leaving journalists in place waiting for breaking news to occur, smaller staff can be assigned as needed to wherever there are breaking stories, either by commuting to the physical location or by synthesizing reports from remote sources. An even more controversial practice, sometimes described as a reaction to declining resources rather than a legitimate cost-saving measure, is to rely on and reprint information from [[press release]]s written by [[public relations]] professionals working for people or companies that are the subject of an article, or have an interest in an article, without spending the resources to verify or conduct independent research on the matter. Another practice that limits news bureaux is [[embedded reporter|embedded reporting]], whereby [[war correspondent]]s travel under the care of military units rather than at their own direction. The ability to quickly and safely travel throughout a war zone, and to obtain interviews with soldiers and coverage of important conflicts, appeals to news media, but at the cost of journalistic independence and, according to some, objectivity.
==Nontraditional bureaux==
The interaction between professional journalists, witnesses, and news subjects has evolved considerably. Whereas news subjects and bystanders were once treated simply as [[witnesses]] to be interviewed for a [[news story]], media have now accepted them as part of the news process. There are many antecedents to [[Citizen journalism]]. For example, meteorologists would count on amateurs to gather weather data to report, or interview willing subjects unrelated to a news story for "[[man on the street]]" interviews. As early as the 1930s the [[Soviet Union]] encouraged millions of amateur [[People's correspondent]]s to expose corruption and otherwise report on news.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14|publisher=Moscow Times|date= July 3, 2006|title=Proletarian Bloggers Celebrate a Milestone|author=Carl Schreck|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2006/07/03/002.html}}</ref> Beginning in the 1970s, media, unable to respond quickly enough to obtain compelling coverage of natural disasters and weather phenomena such as [[tornadoes]] would count on hobbyists for photographs and film footage. With improvements in technology and as [[video camera]]s and [[Videophone|video-equipped cell phone]]s became widely available, they set up formal programs to gather material from nonprofessionals. For example, in August, 2006, [[CNN]] launched "CNN Exchange", by which the public is encouraged to submit "I-Reports" comprising photographs, videos, or news accounts.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-13|publisher=C/Net|title=CNN snatching page out of YouTube's book|author=Greg Sandoval|date=July 30, 2006|url=http://www.news.com/2100-1025-6100139.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel|accessdate=2007-11-14|title=CNN welcoming citizen journalists|author=Scott Leith|date=August 1, 2006|url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=478319}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> More recently newspapers have incorporated [[blogs]], once seen as a threat to conventional news practice, either by creating blogs of their own (and deputizing local or field-specific bloggers as a second, lower-paid tier among their recognized staff of [[independent contractor]]s) or by covering blogs as news sources.
In 2006 [[Reuters]] opened its first virtual news Bureau, staffing real-life reporters in a virtual office in [[Second Life]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14|publisher=USA Today|title=Reuters opens virtual news bureau in 'Second Life'|date=October 10, 2006|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2006-10-16-reuters-second-life_x.htm?POE=TECISVA}}</ref> [[CNN]] followed suit in October 2007, but took a citizen journalism approach, allowing residents of Second Life to submit their own reportage.<ref name="mw">{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14 |publisher=Media Week |title=CNN To Launch Bureau in Second Life Virtual World |author=Mike Shields |date=October 29, 2007 |url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664297 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031060212/http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664297 |archivedate=2007-10-31 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Although the news audience of Second World is relatively small, and declining, media consider it a training ground for themselves and participants, applicable to future virtual news projects.<ref name="mw"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cnn.com/exchange/ CNN exchange] - official site *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071024164148/http://secondlife.reuters.com/ second life] at Reuters
[[Category:News]]
