revision.text:
{{Infobox podcast | title = The Fifth Column Podcast | image = The_Fifth_Column_Podcast_Logo.jpg | host = Kmele Foster, Matt Welch, Michael C. Moynihan | genre = News & Politics | format = MP3 | updates = Weekly | length = 50-120 mins | language = English | began = Apr 1, 2016 | website = {{URL|http://wethefifth.com}} }}
'''The Fifth Column Podcast''' is an American politics, news and humor podcast founded in April, 2016. The show is hosted by [[Kmele Foster]], with co-hosts [[Michael C. Moynihan]], [[Matt Welch]] and produced by contributor [https://www.anthonylfisher.com/ Anthony L. Fisher] and Daniel Bier. The podcast is described as in each episode as an “...almost weekly thoughtful commentary on the news, those who make it and occasionally ourselves”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wethefifth.com/episodes/2018/3/12/stormy-social-media-q-mdf8t-gwmfc-mlw4s-dlwdt-xxtzd-psbc3-xmyrf-6ml8a-bgcn4-ns82z-ny8yb-ww44l-sr9ce-2zhfh-3zbfs-ez68r-zsjyw-ymsts-glnfc-p77pw-mwa47-hb2fy-85b74|title=116 w/ Harry Siegel "Soros' Paid Protest Mobs, Team Woke vs Team Resentment"|last=|first=|date=|website=wethefifth.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The show is closely associated with independent-leaning, libertarian and anarcho-capitalist ideology as presented by the show hosts and guests, but is not explicitly so.
=== Background and Format === '''[http://wethefifth.com/ The Fifth Column Podcast]''' first aired on iTunes April 2, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - iTunes|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The show markets itself as “Analysis. Commentary. Sedition” on Instagram<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/we.the.fifth/|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - Instagram|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and as “@MattWelch @mcmoynihan @Kmele pick apart the news, interrogate their guests and question just about everything #someidiotwrotethis” on Twitter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/wethefifth|title=wethefifth - Twitter|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The introduction to the podcast typically describes itself as: “…your almost weekly rhetorical assault on the news cycle, the people who make it and occasionally ourselves…”. Credit for the shows creation has been attributed to the encouragement of [[Kennedy (commentator)|Kennedy]] (Lisa Kennedy Montgomery) and her husband Dave Lee, who are associates of the hosts. The name of the podcast has been attributed to a suggestion by [[Katherine Mangu-Ward]] as revealed in Episode 13 (3:05 mark)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title="Islamic [REDACTED] and OJ Simpson"|last=|first=|date=June 21, 2016|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The original music that opens and closes the podcast includes a soundbite of F.D.R.’s speech given 1940/05/27 warning prejudices exploited by Fifth [[iarchive:1940-05-27_FDR_Warns_of_Fifth_Column|Columnists]]. (https:archive.org)
=== Reception === ''Reason.com'' regularly promotes The Fifth Column in its ''Hit & Run'' segments<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/04/01/whose-foreign-policy-is-really-dumb-the|title=Whose Foreign Policy Is Really Dumb; the Elephant Man Theory of Beauty Pageants, and ‘Some Idiot Wrote This’—Introducing The Fifth Column Podcast|last=Welch|first=Matt|date=April 1, 2016|website=www.reason.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Other promotions come by way of wearelibertarians.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wearelibertarians.com/libertarian-podcasts/|title=My Top 10 Libertarian Podcasts|last=Spangle|first=Chris|date=July 4, 2016|website=wearelibertarians.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, rampantdiscourse.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rampantdiscourse.com/things-i-like-podcasts/|title=Things I Like: Podcasts|last=Essen|first=Paul|date=November 23, 2016|website=rampantdiscourse.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, postlibertarian.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://postlibertarian.com/tag/the-fifth-column/|title=Trump Junior and Russia|last=|first=|date=July 15, 2017|website=postlibertarian.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and freedombunker.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://freedombunker.com/2017/05/19/should-we-even-care-about-trump-scandals-and-russia-michael-moynihan-and-thad-russell-duke-it-out-on-the-fifth-column/|title=Should we even care about Trump scandals and Russia? Michael Moynihan and Thad Russell duke it on on The Fifth Column|last=|first=|date=May 19, 2017|website=freedombunker.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == <!-- https://rampantdiscourse.com/things-i-like-podcasts/ https://postlibertarian.com/tag/the-fifth-column/ https://wearelibertarians.com/libertarian-podcasts/ https://www.anthonylfisher.com/ https://www.facebook.com/TheFifthColumnPodcast fifthcolumn.podbean.com twitter.com/wethefifth itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column http://www.easycounter.com/report/wethefifth.com http://www.instagram.com/p/BgY35jYn_Y- https://twitter.com/wethefifth https://www.instagram.com/we.the.fifth/ https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2 -->
<!--- Categories - Libertarian, Podcasts, Podcast, Political Commentary--> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:News]] [[Category:Political commentators]] [[Category:Media companies]]

{{Distinguish|The Sound of Music Live (2015)}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Sound of Music Live! | image = [[File:Sound of Music Live! logo.png|250px]] | caption = Promotional poster | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Musical theatre|Musical]] [[drama]] | creator = {{Plainlist| * [[Craig Zadan]] * [[Neil Meron]]}} | based_on = ''[[The Sound of Music]]''
by [[Howard Lindsay]]
[[Russel Crouse]] | developer = | writer = Austin Winsberg | director = {{Plainlist| * [[Rob Ashford]] * [[Beth McCarthy-Miller]]}} | creative_director = | presenter = [[NBC]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Carrie Underwood]] * [[Stephen Moyer]] * [[Audra McDonald]] * [[Laura Benanti]] * [[Christian Borle]] }} | composer = [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Craig Zadan * Neil Meron}} | producer = Priscilla Taussig | editor = | location = [[Grumman Studios]]
[[Bethpage, New York]] | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 135 minutes{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Sound-Music-Live-Carrie-Underwood/dp/B00FWMVVLS|title=The Sound of Music Live!: Movies & TV|accessdate=June 16, 2014}} | company = | distributor = [[Universal Studios Home Entertainment]] | picture_format = Color, [[NTSC]], Widescreen | audio_format = Dolby Digital 5.1 | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|12|05}} | followed_by = ''[[Peter Pan Live!]]'' | website = http://www.nbc.com/sound-of-music/ | website_title = ''The Sound of Music Live!'' | production_website = | channel = [[NBC]] }} '''''The Sound of Music Live!''''' is a [[television special]] that was originally broadcast by NBC on December 5, 2013. Produced by [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], the special was an adaptation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]''. The television special starred [[country music|country]] singer and ''[[American Idol]]'' winner [[Carrie Underwood]] as [[Maria von Trapp]], and was performed and televised [[live television|live]] from [[Grumman Studios]] in [[Bethpage, New York]]. Spearheaded by NBC chairman [[Robert Greenblatt|Bob Greenblatt]], the network positioned the special as being a live [[event television|television "event"]]. In preparing for the broadcast, Meron and Zadan emphasized the logistical challenges that they would face due to the live aspects of the special, and the fact that ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was an adaptation based on the musical itself and not the [[The Sound of Music (film)|1965 film version]]. Meron felt that if the telecast were successful, the concept could become "another kind of entertainment that can exist on TV." By her request, Underwood's casting as Maria was personally endorsed by [[Julie Andrews]], who starred in the 1965 film. The production was met with mixed reviews; much of its criticism was directed towards the casting of Carrie Underwood to play Maria, whom critics (including the real-life [[von Trapp family]]) believed was not experienced enough in theatre to portray such an iconic role. While her vocal performance was praised, her acting was described by critics as "amateur", "lifeless" and lacking emotion. The production was a ratings success for NBC; with a total of 18.62 million live viewers, ''The Sound of Music Live!'' brought the network its highest Thursday night viewership for an entertainment program since the [[Goodnight, Seattle|series finale]] of ''[[Frasier (TV series)|Frasier]]'' in 2004, and prompted NBC to sign Zadan and Meron on to produce more live musicals for the network in the future. ==Plot== Maria Rainer, a [[postulant]] at [[Nonnberg Abbey]] in [[Salzburg]], is contemplating the day she has spent in the mountains ("The Sound of Music"). When she returns to the Abbey, she learns from the Mother Abbess that she is to be the new governess for the von Trappe children. Before she leaves the Abbey, Mother Abbess asks her to teach her the song that she's always singing ("My Favorite Things"). When Maria arrives at the von Trappe house, she is greeted coldly by the Captain and introduced to the children, who enter with military precision. Maria finds that the Captain has emotionally closed himself off since the death of his wife and decides to teach his children the basics of singing to gain their trust and acceptance. A month, later the captain returns home with Elsa Schraeder, whom he is courting, and their friend Max Detweiler, who is looking for the perfect local singing group to perform at the annual Kaltzberg Festival. When his children arrive dressed in clothes Maria had made from her old bedroom curtains he is outraged and embarrassed. Maria then confronts him and tells him how he does not know or understand his children and that they need him but this only upsets him more and he orders her to return to Nonnberg Abbey. However, upon hearing his children sing to Schraeder, his eyes are open to the truth Maria had been speaking and he embraces his children and ask Maria to stay on as governess. He then throws a grand party for Schraeder and when the band plays the [[Ländler]], the captain's youngest son asks Maria to teach him the dance and the captain steps in to help. As the two dance an unspoken attraction begins to arise in the two and Maria puts a stop to the dancing. However, this unspoken attraction did not go unnoticed by Brigitta who confronts Maria on this. Though Maria strongly denies it she begins to realize that Brigitta is telling the truth. Then, Schraeder calls the children out to say good night to the guests and Max is instantly smitten with the idea to have the children sing in the festival and during all the hustle and bustle Maria sneaks off unnoticed and returns to the Abbey, where she confides in the Mother Abbess that she has fallen in love with the captain but that she is ready to take the orders of [[poverty, obedience and chastity]]. The Mother Abbess denies her this and encourages her to take face her problem head-on and to find the life she was born to live. Maria then returns to the von Trapp home and is warmly greeted by the children, who no longer feel the joys of singing due to her sudden departure. When she finds out that the captain intends to marry Schraeder she decides to see her duties through until arrangements can be made for a new governess. However, the political differences between Schraeder and the captain cause the two to realize that they have no future together and she leaves. Meanwhile, the captain confronts Maria and the two admit their feelings for each other. The two agree to marry at the Abbey and while the two are on honeymoon, [[Anschluss|Germany invades Austria]]. When they return, the captain is ordered to accept a commission in the German Navy and report immediately to [[Bremerhaven]]. Maria, thinking quickly, hands the Admiral the program for the Kaltzberg Festival showing that the von Trapp Family Singers are scheduled to perform, so the captain couldn’t possibly leave right away. They are granted permission to perform. During the finale, Max announces that a guard of honor is waiting to escort the captain away as soon as the concert is over. Maria leads the family in one more song to which they escape to one by one and flee to the Abbey. The Nazi soldiers search the Abbey for the von Trapps to no avail, as the family decides to flee Austria over the mountains with Maria's help.{{cite web|url=http://www.masterworksbroadway.com/music/the-sound-of-music-%E2%80%93-music-from-the-nbc-television-event-2013|title=The Sound of Music – Music from the NBC Television Event 2013|work=[[Masterworks Broadway]]|publisher=[[Sony Music Entertainment]]|accessdate=2014-05-19}} ==Cast and crew== :''Cast list adapted from the [[liner notes]] of the soundtrack.''{{cite AV media notes|title=[[The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event]]|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=3|id=88843 79814 2}} [[File:Carrie Underwood 2, 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Carrie Underwood in 2012]] [[File:Stephen Moyer cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Stephen Moyer]] ;Main {{Div col}} * [[Carrie Underwood]] as [[Maria von Trapp]] (née Rainer) * [[Stephen Moyer]] as [[Georg von Trapp|Captain Georg von Trapp]] * [[Audra McDonald]] as [[Virgilia, Mother Abbess|Mother Abbess]] * [[Laura Benanti]] as Elsa Schräder / Fräulein Schweiger * [[Christian Borle]] as [[Franz Wasner|Max Detweiler]] {{div col end}} ;Supporting {{Div col}} * [[Jessica Molaskey]] as Sister Berthe * [[Elena Shaddow]] as Sister Sophia * [[Christiane Noll]] as Sister Margaretta * [[Ariane Rinehart]] as [[Agathe von Trapp|Liesl von Trapp]] * Michael Nigro as [[Rupert von Trapp|Friedrich von Trapp]] * Ella Watts-Gorman as [[Maria Franziska von Trapp|Louisa von Trapp]] * Joe West as [[Werner von Trapp|Kurt von Trapp]] * [[Sophia Anne Caruso]] as [[Hedwig von Trapp|Brigitta von Trapp]] * Grace Rundhaug as [[Johanna von Trapp|Marta von Trapp]] * Peyton Ella as [[Martina von Trapp|Gretl von Trapp]] * Michael Campayno as Rolf * Sean Cullen as Franz * [[Kristine Nielsen]] as Frau Schmidt * C.J. Wislon as Herr Zeller * [[Michael Park (actor)|Michael Park]] as Baron Elberfeld * Paula Leggett Chase as Baroness Elberfeld and a nun * [[John Michael Bolger|John Bolger]] as Admiral von Scheiber {{div col end}} Benanti had previously portrayed Maria von Trapp on Broadway in 1998. [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], who had previously worked with Borle on the NBC musical drama television series ''[[Smash (U.S. TV series)|Smash]]'', served as [[executive producer]]s.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/459565/first-look-carrie-underwood-as-maria-in-the-sound-of-music|title=First Look: Carrie Underwood as Maria in The Sound of Music|first=Tierney|last=Bricker|work=''[[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]''|publisher=[[E!| E! Entertainment Television, LLC]]. A Division of [[NBCUniversal]]|date=September 16, 2013|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/sound-of-music/about//#credits?par=The%20Sound%20of%20Music%20Live!|title=The Sound of Music Live! - All Bios - Newest|work=''[[NBC|NBC.com]]''|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013}} Other credits include [[Rob Ashford]] and [[Beth McCarthy-Miller]] as [[Film director|directors]], Ashford also was the [[choreographer]], Priscilla Taussig served as [[Television producer|producer]], David Chase as [[music director]] and Derek McLane as [[production designer]]. [[Catherine Zuber]] was [[costume designer]] and Bernie Telsey was the [[casting director]]. The production is taken from the book by [[Howard Lindsay]] and [[Russel Crouse]] and is based off the [[memoir]], ''[[The Story of the Trapp Family Singers]]'' by Maria von Trapp.{{cite AV media notes|title=[[The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event]]|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=23|id=88843 79814 2}} ==Development and promotion== On June 30, 2012, NBC's chairman [[Robert Greenblatt|Bob Greenblatt]] announced the network's plans to broadcast a live adaptation of the Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-NBC-Craig-ZadanNeil-Meron-to-Present-Live-Broadcast-of-THE-SOUND-OF-MUSIC-20120629#ixzz2CoUEezC5|title=NBC & Craig Zadan/Neil Meron to Present Live Broadcast of THE SOUND OF MUSIC!|author=BWW News Desk|date=June 30, 2012|work=''broadwayworld.com''|publisher=Wisdom Digital Media|accessdate=January 9, 2014}} On November 30, 2012, the network announced that [[country music]] and [[American Idol (season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]'', winner performer Carrie Underwood would star as Maria von Trapp in the production. In a statement, Greenblatt justified Underwood's involvement, saying that "[Maria] was an iconic woman who will now be played by an iconic artist."{{cite web|title=Carrie Underwood to Star as Maria von Trapp on TV's The Sound of Music|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20652388,00.html|last=Silverman|first=Stephen M.|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=November 30, 2012|accessdate=November 30, 2012}} On September 16, 2013, NBC revealed the full cast of the special, and released a promotional image depicting Underwood as Maria von Trapp, wearing blond braids and a [[dirndl]], referencing one of [[Julie Andrews]]' "most iconic moments" from the [[The Sound of Music (film)|film adaptation]].{{cite journal|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=NBC to re-air 'Sound of Music Live!' on Saturday|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=Time Inc.|date=December 10, 2013|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/12/10/sound-of-music-live-encore/|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/carrie-underwood-stars-maria-sound-music-live-poster-article-1.1458571|title=Carrie Underwood dons dirndl for NBC's 'The Sound of Music Live!' poster|first=Margaret|last=Eby|work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=September 17, 2013}} Prior to being cast, Underwood personally asked Andrews for her endorsement of the role and the production, stating that "whenever I do a cover of somebody's song or whatever, I always get permission of the artist first."{{cite web|url=http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/134782/Carrie-Underwood-Reveals-Julie-Andrews-Gave-Sound-Of-Music-Live-TV-Special-Her-Seal-Of-Approval|title=Carrie Underwood Reveals Julie Andrews Gave 'Sound Of Music Live!' TV Special Her Seal Of Approval|last=McGrath|first=Rachel|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2014|work=[[Gigwise|Entertainmentwise]]|publisher=[[Gigwise|Giant Digital]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/487610/carrie-underwood-dishes-on-the-sound-of-music-live-and-how-she-got-julie-andrew-s-seal-of-approval-watch-now|title=Carrie Underwood Dishes on The Sound of Music Live! and How She Got Julie Andrew's Seal of Approval—Watch Now!|last=Aguilera|first=LeAnne|date=December 4, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2013|work=[[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]}} Produced on a budget of around $9 million, ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was broadcast live from a soundstage built at Grumman Studios in [[Bethpage, New York]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/carrie-underwood-s-sound-of-music-special-to-air-live-from-bethpage-1.6528060|title=Carrie Underwood's 'Sound of Music' special to air live from Bethpage|last1=Amodio|first1=Joseph|date=December 2, 2013|website=[[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} NBC, as well as producers [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], emphasized that the production was not a remake of the film, but an adaptation of the musical itself; Meron iterated that "the audience will discover, within the first few minutes of watching the show, that they are not seeing a TV version of the movie. They'll know right away it's ''The Sound of Music'', but it's a different ''Sound of Music'' than they are accustomed to seeing on film." Meron felt that if successful, the broadcast could "open the door to another kind of entertainment that can exist on TV." He also praised the involvement of Underwood as the star of the production, believing that she was a quick learner, and "has all of the qualities of Maria." Greenblatt was highly supportive of the project, as he was, in the words of Zadan, a "passionate devotee of theater". Zadan considered the production to be "one of the profoundly complicated, amazing experiences we’ve ever had", noting the additional challenges created by the live broadcast.{{cite web|title=‘Sound of Music Live’: Producers Call It a ‘Profoundly Complicated, Amazing Experience’|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/sound-of-music-live-a-profoundly-complicated-amazing-experience-1200925997/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 9, 2013}}{{cite web|title=NBC's 'Sound of Music' Producers on Live Show Fears and Big Expectations (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nbcs-sound-music-producers-live-661941|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]| last=Ng|first=Philiana|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 9, 2013}} Promoted by NBC as a "three-hour holiday event", ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was aired as part of a push by NBC to air more live entertainment specials. Among its most popular programs in recent years have been those with live components (such as ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' and ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''); NBC's Jennifer Salke believed that the increased level of [[social networking service|social network]] interaction possible in a live broadcast, along with the feeling of being part of an "event", would encourage viewers to watch the special live instead of [[Video on-demand|on-demand]] or from a recording. NBC's previous attempt at event television, ''[[The Million Second Quiz]]'', was met with mixed reviews and viewership, but NBC did indicate that [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]]'s advertising throughout the series brought a higher level of [[Brand awareness|awareness]] to the brand.{{cite web|title=NBC Plots Aggressive Live Programming Strategy|url=http://adage.com/article/media/nbc-plots-aggressive-live-programming-strategy/245473/|work=[[AdAge]]|publisher=[[Crain Communications]]|last=Poggi|first=Jeanine|date=December 2, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} The television special was also the first live musical special in almost fifty years on NBC.{{cite AV media notes|title=The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=7|id=88843 79814 2}} Retail chain [[Walmart]] served as the presenting sponsor for ''The Sound of Music Live!''. NBC also produced five themed Walmart commercials to air throughout the special, featuring scenes of a family using products from the store set to songs from ''The Sound of Music''. The five ads were timed to air during the commercial break following the scene where the song was featured; NBC's advertising chief Dan Lovinger considered the ads to be a way to "enhance the excitement" of the presentation for families.{{cite web|title=Walmart Ads for NBC’s "Sound of Music" Will Sound Just Like the Show|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/walmart-ads-for-nbcs-sound-of-music-will-sound-just-like-the-show-1200922060/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Steinberg|first=Brian|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 12, 2013}} ==Musical numbers== :''The list of musical numbers is taken from the actual broadcast and are in order as they appear in the broadcast and include the characters' names who perform the song.'' {{Div col}} * "Preludium" – Nuns * "[[The Sound of Music (song)|The Sound of Music]]" – Maria * "[[Maria (1959 song)|Maria]]" – Sister Berthe, Sister Sophia, Sister Margaretta, and the Mother Abbess * "[[My Favorite Things (song)|My Favorite Things]]" – Maria and the Mother Abbess * "My Favorite Things" (reprise 1) – Maria * "[[Do-Re-Mi]]" – Maria and the children * "[[Sixteen Going on Seventeen]]" – Rolf and Liesl * "[[The Lonely Goatherd]]" – Maria and the children * "How Can Love Survive" – Max and Elsa * "The Sound of Music" (reprise) – The children, the captain, and Maria * "The Grand Waltz" (instrumental) * "[[Ländler]]" (instrumental) * "So Long, Farewell" – The children & Party Guests * "[[Climb Ev'ry Mountain]]" – Mother Abbess * "The Lonely Goatherd" (reprise) – Max and the children * "Do-Re-Mi" (reprise) – The children * "Do-Re-Mi" (reprise 2) – The captain * "The Sound of Music" (reprise 2) – The captain and the children * "My Favorite Things" (reprise) – The children and Maria * "[[No Way to Stop It]]" – Elsa, Max and the captain. * "[[Something Good (Richard Rodgers song)|Something Good]]" – Maria and the captain * "Processional" – Nuns * "Maria" (reprise) – Nuns * "Sixteen Going on Seventeen" (reprise) – Maria and Liesl * "Do-Re-Mi" (reprise 3) – Maria, the children, and the captain * "[[Edelweiss (song)|Edelweiss]]" – The captain, Maria, and the children * "So Long, Farewell" (reprise) – Maria, the children, and the captain * "Finale Ultimo: Climb Ev'ry Mountain" - Nuns * "End Credits" (instrumental) {{div col end}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== Prior to the broadcast, members of the real-life von Trapp family were critical of casting Underwood to play Maria, agreeing with the notion that she would be a good singer but a poor actor. They suggested that [[Anne Hathaway]], who played [[Fantine]] in the [[Les Misérables (2012 film)|2012 film adaptation]] of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' for which she won the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]], would have been a better choice.{{cite web|last=Rothman|first=Michael|title=Who the Von Trapps Wish Could Replace Carrie Underwood in ‘The Sound of Music Live’|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/12/who-the-von-trapps-wish-could-replace-carrie-underwood-in-the-sound-of-music-live/|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=December 6, 2013|date=December 5, 2013}} ''The Sound of Music Live!'' received mixed reviews from entertainment critics, commending the show for its scope and supporting cast while questioning Underwood's acting capabilities. Kevin Fallon of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' wrote: "Naturally, Underwood sounded astounding, as alive as those damned hills, every time she was asked to stand on top of things and belt. But whether it was because of nerves or lack of experience, her acting was painfully lifeless and amateur throughout the first two thirds of the lengthy ordeal. The singer, it seems, is a proud graduate of the school of 'If I don't blink, they'll think I'm acting!'"{{cite web|title=‘Sound of Music Live!’ Review: The Hills Are Barely Alive| url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-review-the-hills-are-barely-alive.html|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|publisher=[[The Newsweek Daily Beast Company]]|last=Fallon|first=Kevin|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Verne Gay of ''[[Newsday]]'' liked Underwood's performance, commenting that not only could she sing, but "she is a luminous stage presence who had the guts to take on one of the most iconic roles of the stage or screen."{{Cite web|url = http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/columnists/verne-gay/sound-of-music-and-carrie-underwood-largely-a-success-1.6550556|title = 'Sound of Music' -- and Carrie Underwood -- largely a success|date = December 5, 2013|accessdate =December 6, 2013|work = [[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|last = Gay|first = Verne}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described the production "as lifeless as [its] alpine backdrops."{{cite web |title=TV Review: '' 'The Sound of Music Live!' '' |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/the-sound-of-music-live-tv-review-nbc-1200915170/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Lowry|first=Brian |date= December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Marc Bernardin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' commended the production's aesthetics but called it a "very expensive karaoke", and he wrote that Underwood "doesn’t acquit herself so well when it comes to the carrying the emotional weight of the production." He also panned Moyer, criticizing his vocal performance and describing "his attempt at conveying an emotional hollowness" as "mildly constipated" and "clenched." However, he lauded Benanti, Borle and McDonald's "strong" performances.{{Cite web|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/sound-music-live-tv-review-663346|title = The Sound of Music Live!: TV Review|date =December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013|work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|last = Bernardin|first = Marc}} ===Ratings=== 18.62 million viewers watched ''The Sound of Music Live!'', making it the most-watched program of the night. It had a 4.6 rating, 13 share in the 18–49 demographic, which led all networks.{{cite news |url= http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/12/06/thursday-final-ratings-the-big-bang-theory-once-upon-a-time-the-millers-greys-anatomy-scandal-adjusted-down/220522/ |title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'The Big Bang Theory' & 'The X Factor' Adjusted Up; 'Once Upon a Time in Wonderland', 'The Millers', 'Grey's Anatomy' & Scandal' Adjusted Down|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It attracted NBC's largest non-sports Thursday audience since the [[Goodnight, Seattle|series finale]] of ''[[Frasier]]'' in 2004 (which averaged 22.6 million viewers),{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}} and NBC's largest non-sports audience on any night since the [[2007 Golden Globe Awards]].{{cite news |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/the-sound-of-music-live-ratings-18-5-million-viewers-1.6554021 |title='The Sound of Music Live!' ratings: 18.5 million viewers |last=Gay |first=Verne |work=[[Newsday]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} The special performed the best with women in the 25–54 demographic, reaching a household rating of 7.0 for that demographic during the primetime broadcast.{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/sound-of-music-ratings-sing-for-nbc-thursday-night-1200925968/ |title='Sound of Music' Ratings Sing for NBC Thursday Night |last=Weisman |first=Jon |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It did particularly well in Oklahoma City, the capital of Underwood's home state, where it was watched by 28% of TV viewers.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-nbc-ratings/3890653/ |title='Sound of Music' was ratings high|last=Levin |first=Gary|work=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} At least 38.69 million viewers watched a portion of ''The Sound of Music Live!''. Factoring in DVR viewership over the week following the broadcast, the special was viewed by 21.84 million, with 3.1 million within the first three days.{{cite web|title=‘The Sound Of Music’ Continues To Echo Across The Ratings Landscape|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/the-sound-of-music-continues-to-echo-across-the-ratings-landscape/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Ratings for The Sound of Music Live! Swell to Nearly 22 Million with DVR Playback|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/185818-Ratings-for-The-Sound-of-Music-Live-Swell-to-Nearly-22-Million-with-DVR-Playback|work=Playbill|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Live ‘Sound of Music’ Added 3 Million Delayed Viewers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/business/media/live-sound-of-music-added-3-million-delayed-viewers.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Carter|first=Bill|date=December 10, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} Following its original airing, an encore presentation of ''The Sound of Music Live!'' aired on December 14, 2013, attracting 3.1 million viewers. It notably displaced one of NBC's two traditional airings of the film ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' (the other being on Christmas Eve), which was bumped ahead to December 20, 2013.{{cite journal|last=Friedlander|first=Whitney|title=NBC to Re-Air ‘The Sound of Music Live!’|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 10, 2013|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/nbc-sound-of-music-live-reair-1200941859/|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}{{cite journal|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=NBC to re-air 'Sound of Music Live!' on Saturday|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher= Entertainment Weekly Inc|date=December 10, 2013|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/12/10/sound-of-music-live-encore/|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/ask_sam/article_251bd091-1888-5c87-86d8-8137dc17cedf.html|title=Ask Sam: 'It's a Wonderful Life' pre-empted by 'Sound of Music Live'|work=[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway|BH Media]]|date=December 20, 2013|accessdate=December 20, 2013}} NBC's Bob Greenblatt considered the production to be a success, and signed Meron and Zadan to produce another live musical for the 2014 holiday season. Greenblatt felt that there were enough recognizable, family-friendly musicals to make events like ''The Sound of Music Live!'' an annual tradition, and he indicated that NBC received e-mails and phone calls from various theatrical rightsholders, expressing interest in having their musicals adapted in a similar fashion, In January 2014, NBC announced that it would broadcast a live version of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' in December 2014, and at NBC's [[upfronts]] in May 2014, Greenblatt announced that NBC had also obtained rights to produce an adaptation of ''[[The Music Man]]'', although the network did not announce any timeframe for the production.{{cite web|title=NBC Says It Will Put On a Show, Again| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/10/arts/television/a-network-is-buoyed-by-sound-of-music-ratings.html?ref=television&_r=0|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Carter|first=Bill|date=December 9, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2013}}{{cite web|title=NBC Announces 'Music Man' Live TV Production|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6084818/nbc-announces-music-man-live-tv-production|website=Billboard|accessdate=5 December 2014}}{{cite news |last=Frizell |first=Sam |date=January 19, 2014 |title=NBC Announces ''Peter Pan'' for Next Live Production |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2014/01/19/nbc-announces-peter-pan-for-next-live-production/ |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=November 17, 2014 }} It was later revealed that ''The Music Man'' project was put on hold for a live performance of ''[[The Wiz Live!|The Wiz]]''.[http://www.ew.com/article/2015/03/30/wiz-nbc The Wiz is NBC's next live musical] Entertainment Weekly, Retrieved October 4, 2015 Interest in the concept also spread to competing networks: in April 2014, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] announced that it would produce a [[Grease: Live|live production]] of ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'', which aired in January 2016.{{cite web|title='Grease' Live Coming to Fox TV|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6070137/grease-live-coming-to-fox-tv|website=Billboard|accessdate=5 December 2014}} NBC aired ''[[Hairspray Live!]]'' later that year.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/kenny-leon-jerry-mitchell-and-harvey-fierstein-will-bring-hairspray-to-life-for-nbc-broadcast-date-set-387509# "Kenny Leon, Jerry Mitchell and Harvey Fierstein Will Bring 'Hairspray' to Life for NBC; Broadcast Date Set "], Playbill, February 18, 2016 The special also had an influence on viewership for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s annual broadcast of the [[The Sound of Music (film)|1965 film version]] of ''The Sound of Music''; with 6.5 million viewers and a 1.3 share, it was ABC's highest-rated airing of the film since 2007, although it was beaten by NBC's ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''. ===Accolades=== {{expand section|Additional accolades|date=July 2014}} The broadcast has been nominated for four Emmy Awards for the [[66th Primetime Emmy Awards]] for Outstanding Music Direction, Outstanding Directing for a Variety Special, Outstanding Special Class Program and Outstanding Technical Direction, Camerawork, Video Control for a Miniseries, Movie, or Special in 2014.Whitaker, Sterling (July 11, 2014). [http://theboot.com/carrie-underwood-the-sound-of-music-live-emmy-nominations/ "Carrie Underwood's 'The Sound of Music Live!' Earns Four Primetime Emmy Nominations"]. ''The Boot''. Taste of Country Network. Retrieved July 17, 2014.Ragusa, Tammy (July 11, 2014). "[http://www.countryweekly.com/news/emmy-nods-carrie-underwoods-sound-music-live-and-voice "Emmy Nods for Carrie Underwood's "''The Sound of Music Live!''" and "''The Voice''""]. ''[[Country Weekly]]''. American Media, Inc. Retrieved July 17, 2014.Leahey, Andrew (July 11, 2014). [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/carrie-underwoods-music-receives-four-emmy-nods-20140711 "Carrie Underwood's 'Music' Receives Four Emmy Nods"]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' Retrieved July 17, 2014.Wyland, Sarah (July 14, 2014). [http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2014/07/14/carrie-underwoods-the-sound-of-music-receives-emmy-nominations/ "Carrie Underwood’s ‘The Sound of Music’ Receives Emmy Nominations"]. [[Great American Country]]. Scripps Networks. LLC. Retrieved July 17, 2014. It won the Emmy for Outstanding Technical Direction, Camerawork, Video Control for a Miniseries, Movie, or Special.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/08/creative-arts-emmy-awards-2014-winners-live-819681/ |title=Creative Arts Emmy Awards: ‘Saturday Night Live’, HBO Grab Most Trophies — Full List Of Winners |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=August 16, 2014 |first=Lisa |last=de Moraes |accessdate=December 5, 2014}} ==Soundtrack== {{Main|The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event}} A [[soundtrack]] for the broadcast was released on December 3, 2013{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music (Music from the NBC Television Event) by Various Artists - iTunes album detail page|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/sound-music-music-from-nbc/id731630716|work=[[iTunes Stores]]|publisher=[[Apple, Inc.|Apple, Inc]]|accessdate=17 April 2014}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-the-sound-of-music-2013-nbc-television-cast-mw0002593930|title=Carrie Underwood: The Sound of Music (2013 NBC Television Cast)|work=[[AllMusic]]|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|date= December 3, 2013|accessdate=April 21, 2014}} and consists of 22 studio recordings.{{Cite news|url=http://www.statejournal.com/story/23776848/sony-masterworks-releases-television-soundtrack-to-nbcs-live-broadcast-of-the-sound-of-music-starring-six-time-grammy-winner-carrie-underwood|title=Sony Masterworks Releases Television Soundtrack To NBC's Live Broadcast of 'The Sound of Music' Starring Six-Time Grammy Winner Carrie Underwood|accessdate=November 14, 2013|work=[[State Journal|The State Journal]]|publisher=WorldNow and WVSTATE|date=October 24, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203095935/http://www.statejournal.com/story/23776848/sony-masterworks-releases-television-soundtrack-to-nbcs-live-broadcast-of-the-sound-of-music-starring-six-time-grammy-winner-carrie-underwood|archivedate=December 3, 2013}} [[Walmart]] outlets exclusively released a nine-track instrumental ([[sing-along]]) bonus CD with the soundtrack.{{cite web|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/32703614|title=The Sound Of Music (2013 NBC Television Cast) Soundtrack (Walmart Exclusive) (2CD), Carrie Underwood: Country : Walmart.com|work=Walmart.com|publisher=[[Walmart|Wal-Mart Stores, Inc]]|accessdate=December 10, 2013}} It peaked at number 17 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2013-12-21/billboard-200|title=Billboard 200: Dec 21, 2013 (Billboard Chart Archive)|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=December 24, 2013}} and number 2 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Soundtracks chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2013-12-21/soundtracks|title=Soundtracks: Dec 21, 2013 (Billboard Chart Archive)|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=December 24, 2013}} The soundtrack had sold 103,000 copies as of January 2, 2014.{{cite news |title=Country Album Chart News: The Week of January 2, 2013: Garth Brooks, Duck Dynasty, Cassadee Pope, Danielle Bradbery & Scotty McCreery |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-january-2-2013-garth-brooks-duck-dynasty-cassadee-pope-danielle-bradbery-scotty-mccreery |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |publisher=Roughstock |date=January 2, 2014 |accessdate=January 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102223559/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-january-2-2013-garth-brooks-duck-dynasty-cassadee-pope-danielle-bradbery-scotty-mccreery |archivedate=January 2, 2014 |df= }} ==Home media release== A [[DVD]] of the special was released on December 17, 2013,{{Cite news|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/NBC-to-Release-THE-SOUND-OF-MUSIC-LIVE-on-DVD-Dec-17-20131123|title= NBC to Release THE SOUND OF MUSIC LIVE! on DVD, Dec 17|accessdate=November 25, 2013|work=Broadway World|publisher=Wisdom Digital Media|author=BWW News Desk|date=November 23, 2013}} through [[Universal Studios Home Entertainment]]. The DVD includes a behind-the-scenes look, titled "The Making of ''The Sound of Music Live!''"{{cite news|title='Slo 'Mo', Holi-GAYS, amd [sic] Sound of Music Live!' DVD coming up|url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/lgbt/Slo-Mo-Holi-GAYS-amd-Sound-of-Music-Live-DVD-coming-up/45467.html|accessdate=December 14, 2013|newspaper=Windy City Times|publisher=Windy City Media Group|publication-place=Chicago, IL|date=December 10, 2013}} and a preview of the soundtrack.''The Sound of Music Live!'' [[DVD]]. 2013. [[Universal Studios Home Entertainment]]. Main Menu. It was released on DVD in Canada on January 7, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.ca/Sound-Music-Live-Bilingual/dp/B00FX7FC30/|title=The Sound of Music - Live (Bilingual): Carrie Underwood, Stephen Moyer, Neil Meron;Craig Zadan: DVD|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] (Canada), Amazon.com, Inc|accessdate=December 24, 2013}} ==See also== {{Portal|Musical Theatre|Television in the United States}} * [[2013 in American television]] * ''[[Peter Pan Live!]]'' (2014), NBC * ''[[The Sound of Music Live (2015)|''The Sound of Music Live'' (2015)]]'', UK TV production * ''[[The Wiz Live!]]'' (2015), NBC * ''[[Hairspray Live!]]'' (2016), NBC * ''[[Grease: Live]]'' (2016), Fox * ''[[A Christmas Story Live!]]'' (2017), Fox * ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert]]'' (2018), NBC * ''[[Rent: Live]]'' (2019), Fox * ''[[Hair Live!]]'' (2019), NBC ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.nbc.com/sound-of-music/}} * {{IMDb title|3141866|The Sound of Music Live!}} *{{rottentomatoes|the_sound_of_music_live}} *{{metacritic television|the-sound-of-music-live!}} {{NBC Live!}} {{Rodgers and Hammerstein}} {{The Story of the Trapp Family Singers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sound of Music Live!}} [[Category:2010s American television specials]] [[Category:2013 television specials]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Live television programs]] [[Category:Musical television films]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:NBC television specials]] [[Category:The Sound of Music]] [[Category:Television programs based on plays]] [[Category:Television remakes of films]] [[Category:Television shows filmed in New York (state)]] [[Category:Television shows set in Austria]] [[Category:Trapp family]] [[Category:Works based on actual events]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/ZeR0101MiNt|ZeR0101MiNt]]: The "name" parameter is about the event name which is "Eurovision Dance Contest". Also, it is needed for the link to the 2008 article.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Song Contest |name = Eurovision Dance Contest |year=2009 |logo = |final = Postponed indefinitely{{cite web|url=http://esckaz.com/edc/|title=Eurovision Dance Contest has been put on hold|date=2010-01-19|publisher=''ESCKaz''|accessdate=2010-01-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/page/news?id=2913|title=3rd Eurovision Dance Contest postponed to 2010|publisher=EBU|accessdate=2009-05-28}} |presenters = |host = [[İctimai Television]] (İTV){{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1879|title=Dance Contest 2009 to Baku, Azerbaijan}} |venue = [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]], [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] |vote = |debut = {{esc|Belarus|Dance}} |return = |withdraw = {{esc|Austria|Dance}}
{{esc|Finland|Dance}}
{{esc|Lithuania|Dance}}
{{esc|Netherlands|Dance}}
{{esc|Sweden|Dance}} }} [[File:Bedii Gimnastika 026.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]], in Baku.]] The third [[Eurovision Dance Contest]] was originally planned to be organised in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] at the [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]] on 26 September 2009.{{cite web|url=http://esckaz.com/edc/|title=European Broadcasting Union has finally officially confirmed the date of EDC 2009|date=2009-04-02|publisher=''ESCKaz''|accessdate=2009-04-02}} [[İctimai Televiziya və Radio Yayımları Şirkəti|İctimai Television]] was planning to increase the number of participating countries as well as inviting a world-famous star to host the contest, listing [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Kylie Minogue]] and [[Shakira]] as candidates.{{cite web|url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=102659|title=We are negotiating with Jennifer Lopez, Kylie Minogue and Shakira to host the Eurovision Dance 2009 in Azerbaijan}} An additional extravaganza [[open-air concert]] was planned to be held, bringing together ex-participants of the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]], [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest|Junior Eurovision]] and [[Eurovision Dance Contest|Eurovision Dance]] Contests on one stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/page/news?id=1905|title=Baku: More details announced at press conference}} ==Participants== On the date of cancellation, two countries had finished selection of the participating couples for the contest: *{{esc|Azerbaijan|Dance}} – host country *{{esc|Belarus|Dance}} – winners of 3-month long preselection show ''Star Dances'' were [[Yulia Raskina]] and [[Denis Moryasin]]. Producer of the show confirmed that they would take part in Eurovision Dance Contest 2010 if it is organised. *{{esc|Poland|Dance}} – [[Natasza Urbańska]] and Jan Kliment. *{{esc|Portugal|Dance}} – internal selection was expected to take place with the couple being selected from the RTP series ''Dança Comigo''.{{cite web|url=http://eurofire.blog.de/2009/04/15/news-splitter-5950321/|title=News Splitter (208)}} *{{esc|Russia|Dance}} – was set to be represented by professional couple [[Sergey Konovaltsev]] and [[Olga Konovaltseva]], named as participants of the show as early as in May 2008 and confirmed in 2009 edition of Russian version of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]''. ==Cancellation== However, on 28 May 2009, [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) had announced that the contest was postponed at least until Autumn 2010 as "the number of broadcasters that signed up for participation had not reach the desired level". According to a preliminary calculations, at least five countries that were taking part in [[Eurovision Dance Contest 2008]], namely {{esccnty|Austria|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Finland|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Lithuania|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Netherlands|Dance}} and {{esccnty|Sweden|Dance}} had announced withdrawal from the contest, with only {{esccnty|Belarus|Dance}} confirming its participation as a début country. According to contest coordinator on behalf of EBU Tal Barnea "concrete plans for a 2010 autumn event were being developed, with considerable changes to introduce a new programme proposal". These plans were expected to be unveiled in the autumn of 2009. EBU also praised "the commendable work on the next Eurovision Dance Contest already completed by our partners Ictimai Television and the Azerbaijani officials" stating that 2010 edition of the contest was planned to take place in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] as well. In January 2010, EBU Eurovision coordinator, [[Svante Stockselius]], announced that contest has been postponed again, and is now unlikely to happen at all, at least within the next couple of years. He explained this decision was the fact that the popularity of televised dance shows had calmed down recently. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/ Eurovision Dance Contest] *[http://www.esckaz.com/edc ESCKaz.com] {{Eurovision Dance Contest}} [[Category:Eurovision Dance Contest by year]] [[Category:2009 in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:2009 in Europe]] [[Category:Cancelled events]] [[Category:Events in Baku]]

revision.text:
{{external links|date=July 2015}} The term '''use error''' has recently been introduced to replace the commonly used terms '''[[human error]]''' and '''[[user error]]'''. The new term, which has already been adopted by [[international standard]]s organizations for [[medical device]]s (see [[#Use errors in health care]] below for references), suggests that [[accident]]s should be attributed to the circumstances, rather than to the human beings who happened to be there.
==The need for the terminological change== The term "use error" was first used in May 1995 in an [[MD+DI]] guest editorial, [http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error “The Issue Is ‘Use,’ Not ‘User,’ Error,”] by [http://biomed.tamu.edu/people/faculty.php?lname=Hyman William Hyman].<ref>http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error</ref> Traditionally, human errors are considered as a special aspect of [[human factors]]. Accordingly, they are attributed to the human [[Computer operator|operator]], or [[user (computing)|user]]. When taking this approach, we assume that the system design is perfect, and the only source for the use errors is the human operator. For example, the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] (DoD) [[HFACS]] <ref>[http://uscg.mil/careercentral/cg113/docs/ergo_hfacs/hfacs.pdf], Department of Defense Human Factors Analysis and Classification System: A mishap investigation and data analysis tool</ref> classifies use errors attributed to the human operator, disregarding improper design and configuration setting, which often result in missing [[alarms]], or in inappropriate [[alert messaging|alerting]].
The need for changing the term was due to a common [[malpractice]] of the [[Project stakeholder|stakeholder]]s (the responsible organizations, the authorities, journalists) in cases of accidents.<ref>[http://www.lu.se/upload/Trafikflyghogskolan/TR2002-01_ReInventionofHumanError.pdf], Dekker: Reinvention of Human Error</ref> Instead of investing in fixing the error-prone design, management attributed the error to the users. The need for the change has been pointed out by the accident investigators: * Early in 1983, Erik Hollnagel<ref> [https://sites.google.com/site/erikhollnagel2/], Erik Hollnagel home page </ref> pointed out that the term Human Error refers to the outcome, not to the cause. A user action is typically classified as an error only if the results are painful <ref>[http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/Bellagio_M.htm], Hollnagel: Why "Human Error" is a Meaningless Concept</ref> * In the story “Leap of Faith” of his book “Set Phasers on Stun”,<ref>[http://www.aegeanpublishing.com/phaser1.html], Steve Casey: Set Phasers on Stun</ref> Steve Casey suggested that the accident of the [[Indian Airlines Flight 605]] near Bangalor in 1990 could have been avoided, should the investigators of the [[Air France Flight 296]] accident of 1988 past the Mulhouse-Habsheim airport considered the circumstances (exceptional situation), rather than the pilots (human errors). * In his book “Managing the Risks of Organizational Accidents” ([[Organizational models of accidents]]) James Reason explained and demonstrated that often, the circumstances for accidents could have been controlled by the responsible organization, and not by the operators. * In his book “The Field Guide to Understanding Human Errors”,<ref>[http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Sidney Dekker: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error</ref> Sidney Dekker argued that blaming the operators according to “The Old View” results in defensive behavior of operators, which hampers the efforts to learn from near-misses and from accidents.
==Use errors vs. force majeure== A mishap is typically considered as either a use error or a force majeure: <ref name="Weiler">[http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/ITS-Alarms-Apr2011.pdf], Weiler and Harel: Managing the Risks of Use Errors: The ITS Warning Systems Case Study</ref> * A use error is a mishap in which a human operator is involved. Typically, such mishaps are attributed to the failure of the human operator <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Dekker, 2007: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error </ref> * A force majeure is a mishap that does not involve a human being in the chain of events preceding the event.
==Use errors in health care== In 1998, Cook, Woods and Miller presented the concept of [[hindsight bias]], exemplified by celebrated accidents in medicine, by a workgroup on patient safety .<ref> [http://www.ctlab.org/documents/A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Stories.pdf], Cook RI, Woods DD, Miller C [1998] A Tale of Two Stories: Contrasting Views of Patient Safety </ref> The workgroup pointed at the tendency to attribute accidents in health care to isolated human failures. They provide references to early research about the effect of knowledge of the outcome, which was unavailable beforehand, on later judgement about the processes that led up to that outcome. They explain that in looking back, we tend to oversimplify the situation that the actual practitioners faces. They conclude focusing on the hindsight knowledge prevents our understanding of the richer story, the circumstances of the human error.
According to this position, the term Use Error is formally defined in several [[international standard]]s, such as [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] 62366, [[ISO 14155]] and [[ISO 14971]], to describe : ''an act or omission of an act that results in a different medical device response than intended by the manufacturer or expected by the user.''
[[ISO standards]] about medical devices and procedures provide examples of use errors, which are attributed to human factors, include slips, [[lapses]] and mistakes. Practically, this means that they are attributed to the user, implying the user’s accountability. The U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] glossary of medical devices provides the following explanation about this term:<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/GeneralHospitalDevicesandSupplies/InfusionPumps/ucm202502.htm], FDA, Medical Devices, Glossary</ref>
:"Safe and effective use of a medical device means that users do not make errors that lead to injury and they achieve the desired medical treatment. If safe and effective use is not achieved, use error has occurred. Why and how use error occurs is a [[human factors]] concern."
With this interpretation by ISO and the FDA, the term ‘use error’ is actually synonymous with ‘user error’. Another approach, which distinguishes ‘use errors’ from ‘user errors', is taken by IEC 62366. Annex A includes an explanation justifying the new term: :"This International Standard uses the concept of use error. This term was chosen over the more commonly used term of “human error” because not all errors associated with the use of medical device are the result of oversight or carelessness of the part of the user of the medical device. Much more commonly, use errors are the direct result of poor user interface design."
This explanation complies with “The New View”, which Sidney Dekker suggested as an alternative to “The Old View”. This interpretation favors investigations intended to understand the situation, rather than blaming the operators.
In a 2011 report draft on health IT usability, the U.S. [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) defines "use error" in healthcare IT this way: “Use error is a term used very specifically to refer to user interface designs that will engender users to make errors of commission or omission. It is true that users do make errors, but many errors are due not to user error per se but due to designs that are flawed, e.g., poorly written messaging, misuse of color-coding conventions, omission of information, etc.".<ref>''NISTIR 7804: Technical Evaluation, Testing and Validation of the Usability of Electronic Health Records, Draft, Sept. 2011, pg. 10. '' [https://www.nist.gov/healthcare/usability/upload/Draft_EUP_09_28_11.pdf]</ref>
=== Example of user error === An example of an accident due to a user error is the ecological disaster of 1967 caused by the [[Torrey Canyon]] supertanker. The accident was due to a combination of several exceptional events, the result of which was that the supertanker was heading directly to the rocks. At that point, the captain failed to change the course because the steering control lever was inadvertently set to the Control position, which disconnected the rudder from the wheel at the helm.<ref>Steve Casey, A memento of your service, in Set Phasers on Stun, 1998</ref>
===Examples of user failure to handle system failure=== Examples of the second type are the [[Three Mile Island accident]] described above, the [[New York City blackout of 1977|NYC blackout]] following a storm and the chemical plant disaster in Bhopal, India ([[Bhopal Disaster]]).
==Classifying use errors== The URM Model <ref name="Task-oriented"> [http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/Task-Oriented-SE.pdf], Zonnenshain & Harel: Task-oriented SE, INCOSE 2009 Conference, Singapore</ref> characterizes use errors in terms of the user’s failure to manage a system deficiency. Six categories of use errors are described in a URM document: #Expected faults with risky results; #Expected faults with unexpected results; #Expected user errors in identifying risky situations (this study); #User Errors in handling expected faults; #Expected errors in function selection; #Unexpected faults, due to operating in exceptional states.
==Critics== Erik Hollnagel argues that going from and 'old' view to a 'new' view is not enough. One should go all the way to a 'no' view. This means that the notion of error, whether user error or use error might be destructive rather than constructive. Instead, he proposes to focus on the performance variability of everyday actions, on the basis that this performance variability is both useful and necessary. In most cases the result is that things go right, in a few cases that things go wrong. But the reason is the same. <ref> [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1042821] Hollnagel: Understanding accidents-from root causes to performance variability </ref> Hollnagel expanded on this in his writings about the [[efficiency–thoroughness trade-off principle]] <ref> [http://functionalresonance.com/ETTO_Introduction.html], The ETTO Principle – Efficiency-Thoroughness Trade-Off </ref> of Resilience Engineering, <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409410355] Hollnagel, Paries, Woods, Wreathall (editors): Resilience engineering in practice </ref> and the Resilient Health Care Net. <ref> [http://www.resilienthealthcare.net] the Resilient Health Care Net </ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=38594 IEC 62366:2007 - Medical devices -- Application of usability engineering to medical devices] * [http://uscg.mil/careercentral/cg113/docs/ergo_hfacs/hfacs.pdf Department of Defense Human Factors Analysis and Classification System: A mishap investigation and data analysis tool] * [http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/ITS-Alarms-Apr2011.pdf Managing the Risks of Use Errors: The ITS Warning Systems Case Study ] * [http://www.lu.se/upload/Trafikflyghogskolan/TR2002-01_ReInventionofHumanError.pdf The re-invention of human error] * [http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/Bellagio_M.htm Why "Human Error" is a Meaningless Concept] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260 Dekker: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error] * [http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/GeneralHospitalDevicesandSupplies/InfusionPumps/ucm202502.htm FDA Medical Devices Glossary] * [http://sunnyday.mit.edu/ Nancy Leveson home page] * [http://www.ctlab.org/documents/A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Stories.pdf Cook RI, Woods DD, Miller C 1998, A Tale of Two Stories] * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1042821 Hollnagel: Understanding accidents-from root causes to performance variability] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409410355 Hollnagel, Paries, Woods, Wreathall (editors): Resilience engineering in practice] * [http://functionalresonance.com/ETTO_Introduction.html The ETTO Principle – Efficiency-Thoroughness Trade-Off] * [http://www.resilienthealthcare.net the Resilient Health Care Net] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260 Dekker, 2007: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error]

revision.text:
{{notability|date = December 2008}}
A '''Zero Waste Event''' (or "ZeeWee" as it has been nicknamed) is one in which event organizers plan ahead to reduce solid waste from the event, reuse various elements such as banners, and set up Zero-Waste Stations for those recyclable and compostable materials such as [[paper cup]]s, food scraps, and plastic [[water bottle]]s that are generated by the event. ZeeWees can range from large scale sports events to weddings and parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sconnect.org/bizdev/conference/ |title=Future of Business Conference- Sustainable Strategies for 2013 — Sustainable Connections |publisher=Sconnect.org |date=2013-04-26 |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sconnect.org/bizdev/tzw/TZW08_insert_v4.pdf/ |format=PDF |title=Think Local - Buy Local : Be waste Free |publisher=Sconnect.org|accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref><ref>[http://sustainabletransforum.ca/presentations.html] {{dead link|date=May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://theredbarncooperative.wordpress.com/2008/06/15/jill-donello-zero-in-on-zero-waste/ |title=Jill Donello – Zero In on Zero Waste | |publisher=Theredbarncooperative.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref>
==Background== As sustainability becomes ever more accepted as a concept within organizations and communities across the nation, the idea of [[Zero waste|Zero Waste]] Events is spreading. Additionally, the steady expansion of recycling and commercial composting infrastructure makes it possible to offer recycling and food composting at events in many locations. Increasingly [https://web.archive.org/web/20120322144442/http://zerowasteevents.org/protocol/ Zero Waste Events] are sharing best practices and developing new ways to divert event materials from landfills.
==Strategy== ZeeWee's utilize many if not all of the following strategies.
'''Front-end waste prevention''' * Eliminating race packets in favor of emailed sponsor coupons for participants; * Eliminating commercial [[bottled water]] distribution in favor of bulk water stations and compostable cups; * Purchasing recycled content products, from event [[t-shirt]]s to paper products; and * Providing discounted entries or incentives for participants who travel to the event using alternative transportation. <ref>[http://www.skitosea.com/content/green_team/green_team.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009153628/http://www.skitosea.com/content/green_team/green_team.asp |date=October 9, 2008 }}</ref>
'''Reuse of event equipment''' * Reusable, weatherproof banners and stands; * Adaptable date panels on banners and signs so they can be reused year after year; and * Use of durable dishware "lending libraries"<ref>[http://www.re-sources.org/wastereduction.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925211512/http://www.re-sources.org/wastereduction.htm |date=September 25, 2008 }}</ref> instead of always buying disposables.
'''Recycling event materials''' * Many items from unsoiled paper, cardboard, glass, [[plastic bottle]]s and jugs, aluminum cans and plastic tarps to corrugated polypropylene signs can be recycled depending on the services available in a given municipality or county. In many cases, such services are less costly than disposal of the same items; * Having a dedicated Recycling Team onsite throughout the event to supervise recycling stations and sort materials to maximize landfill diversion and minimize contamination;<ref>{{cite web|author=Alison Dunn |url=http://runningmagazine.ca/sections/news/vancouver-half-recycles-95-of-waste/ |title=Vancouver half-marathon produces only four bags of garbage - Canadian Running Magazine |publisher=Runningmagazine.ca |date=2013-06-26 |accessdate=2015-05-15 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and * Where programs require subsidy, ZeeWee organizers may use a "green fee" to help move the event toward sustainability by paying for [[Waste minimisation|waste reduction]], buying recycled products, or more recently purchasing carbon offsets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norkarecreation.com/hcrewards.htm |title=Bellingham/Whatcom County Washington |publisher=NorKarecreation.com |date=2013-09-08 |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref>
==2012 Olympics== When the bid was submitted for the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012 Olympic]] and [[2012 Summer Paralympics|Paralympic Games]], [[LOCOG]], The London 2012 Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, pledged not just to host the biggest sporting event in the world but also to stage the first truly sustainable Games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-13160540 |title=London 2012 Olympics team publishes first green report - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref> Central to this was an ambitious target to send zero waste from Games-time venues directly to landfill <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.london2012.com/documents/locog-publications/london-2012-sustainability-plan.pdf |title=Official Reports, Studies, Publications | Downloads | Olympic.org |publisher=London2012.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref> – something that no Games has attempted before. In February 2012 an initiative was launched to share the lessons learnt from delivering a zero waste games with the wider waste and events community.<ref>[http://zerowasteevents.org/front/] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327035411/http://zerowasteevents.org/front/ |date=March 27, 2013 }}</ref>
